title: Homework #1
body: I didn't exactly understand what the 1st homework assignment question is about? Do we have to select options which are related to learning search engine or what?

this is a little off this topic, but since 10^1 has two digits (10^2 three, 10^3 four etc.), wouldn't the numbers with 100 digits be {10^99, 10^99 + 1, ..., 10^100 - 1} ?

in that case, the answer would be 114 (with 227.95 rounded to 228).

could anyone please point out why they use 10^100 for a "100-decimal-digit number", when it has 101 digits?

It states , that the complexity increases exponentially with the size of x. Assume x is a n-bit number. If x is close to $% 2^n - 1 $% , we approximately need to check those $% 2^n $% numbers. Now let y be a n+m-bit prime, assuming the highest bit is not zero. We now increased the pool of numbers to check from $% 2^n $% to $%2^m \cdot 2^n$%, so by increasing the number of bits by m we get in the worst case $% 2^m $% more modulo operations. Thats the trick ;)

Well these are only approximate arguments but i think the idea is clear.

A tweak to the code above, another way to remove the loop

def str_to_bin2(s, pad=7):
output = ""
for c in s:
    b = bin(ord(c))
    b = b[2:] # Cut off the '0b' from the front
    output = '0' * (pad-len(b)) + b + output
return output

Simple. They agree that say a negative integer denotes heads and positive one denotes tails. Alice picks an arbitrary large integer, k. Then she picks x = {-k, k} depending on the outcome of the coin toss, hashes that and sends it over to Bob. Now, in order for Bob to cheat, he needs to either guess the value k or hash all positive and negative integers and search for the hash Alice gave him. In order for Alice to cheat, she needs to find two integers k1, k2 such that H(k1) == H(-k2) or H(-k1) == H(k2). While neither feat is impossible, they both certainly are unfeasible, provided that H is perfect.

Pycryto library version 2.3 for windows (windows installer) available at voidspace.org
but I am not sure this is the same version that the Server is using. Version 2.5 is available
but we are not using the latest...maybe that is the problem? A COMMENT should be added at the beginning of each set of code provided so that we aren't continually "stuck" using the wrong Version?

There was a lot of discussion of the problem in the forums. Basically the "key" has to be the key for the entire alphabet, not a key per character. So if the alphabet is A, there is only one key, also A. If the alphabet is A there are two possible keys, AB or BA. If the alphabet is ABC there are 6 possible keys, ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, and CBA. Now it would have been GREAT for someone to mention in the video what they were defining as a "key" for a substitution cypher because I also intuitively looked at it on a character by character basis.

I thought I would put in a plug for PyScripter here. It's a lightweight IDE, but it gets the job done. If you're already using eclipse, PyDev seems like a good option, but if not, I would suggest trying PyScripter.

Well, I think the deadline for this challenge is pretty rough, so I hope we can discuss approaches to solve some of the harder messages other than the ones given by the hints.

I've solved 11 messages, I think the easiest ones, and I'm looking for ideas to attack the rest of the messages. I've implemented Wiener's attack: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiener%27s_Attack but I didn't find any private key, I guess they're all larger than 1/3 * n^1/4

Any ideas on what else to try?

The OTP depends on a random choice of key among all possible keys. How the individual keys are generated is irrelevant. You can change the question to be one were the chosen key is the outcome of a random (but possibly bias) bit generator. But that would contradict what is in the first paragraph.

I sure hope these are safe...

mint.com -> VeriSign Class 3 Extended Validation -> VeriSign Class 3 G5
lastpass.com -> thawte Extended Validation -> thawte Primary Root

And typing https://ebay.com in chrome leads me to a warning page that the certificate and url don't match:

https://ebay.com -> spages.half.ebay.com -> VeriSign Class 3 Secure Server -> VeriSign Class 3 Public Primary Certification -> Class 3 Public Primary Certification Authority

The only information sent to the server at this point is the IP Address, MAC address?, ciphers and hash that the client can use. This may be enough for the server to guess the client's identity based on a guess, but certainly no server software in its right mind will assume someone who sends this unencrypted sniffable information is necessarily the same person.
I think its 1/3 since I have got only 3 genuine choices here

title: cannot see python editor
body:
I cannot see the character when I enter them into the "run" box.

I can paste from other tool to get success but dont see what I type.

When I debug using print, I tend to just put a few print statements in depending on what sort of errors I'm going. I don't want to have to read through thousands of lines to debug what I'm doing. I want concise messages where I can compare the things that I suspect are not working correctly. I suppose I analyse the error to see what part of the code was missed and then put messages above that part to see why the code never reaches it.

However, everyone things and works differently and I think it's important to use whatever works for you. My friend always uses a debugger, whereas I only tend to resort to that when I can't use print for some reason.

37/male here.

When you are going on freenode, there are a couple extra security measures you may want to use. While not required, getting into a habit of these is good practice.

One of which is already mentioned on the first IRC guide is connecting to Freenode with SSL (through port 7000). This adds the same layer of online protection that you use to do any banking/purchasing online.

When you are logged in you should try to find a unregistered "nickname" and register it. Once you get that done you can go to #freenode channel and request having a "Cloak" applied to your nickname. One of the reasons is that without a cloak someone can easily look up your IP Address through your hostname which usually looks something like "12-34-5-678.LA.fios.verizon" . You can check this with Xchat by right clicking on somebody's (or your own) nickname. With a cloak you are simply seen as "unaffiliated/yournicknamehere."

Hope this helps!

Why?

To pass arguments from the command line you need to use sys.argv. For example:

import sys

def my_function(parameter):
    print parameter

if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(argv) > 1:
        my_function(argv[1])

The if __name__ part calls your function when you run the program, but not when you import the file.

As for your main question, I would say the easiest and most sensible answer is just to put all the functions in one file. If you do want to call a function from a different file, you need to import that file first.

For example,

import  make_hashtable

a = 'udacity'
b = 34
make_hashtable.make_hashtable(a, b)  # note the x.x pattern

Hello! I'm a music student from Finland (drummer..) and I love what I do, but I'd really like to change the direction of my life by applying to university. I'm enthusiastic about mathematics and physics and I spend a lot of time watching documentaries (or nowadays searching for something I haven't seen yet...) and studying independently. This course is simply perfect for me. Hopefully it will help me decide what to do in the future. And it's so nice to get to know you all!

I don't see anything wrong with your code.

When I submit your code it grades as correct, however, it does give this message:

Correct! Although your answer is correct, you might like to try to
find a solution without using the key words if, round or int.

Your solution shouldn't be getting that message. I'm sure Sarah will look into the message, however your solution should still give you the message "You got it right!" as it did for me when I submitted your code.

Did you copy and paste it from another editor? do you have any spaces or tabs anywhere that could be causing the Udacity interpreter to grade this as incorrect?

@ked4r: Are you saying that you can prove that chromatic number problem is not in NP? I want to see a proof or at least a sketch then ;).

In the meantime I will repeat my explanation why I highly doubt that you can prove it. Let's assume that P=NP. From it follows that co-NP=co-P=P=NP. Since chromatic number problem is in co-NP, it follows that it is in NP. Now, if you can prove that chromatic number is not in NP we will arrive at contradiction and conclude that P!=NP.

The bottom line is that it is very hard to prove that co-NP problem is not in NP. The correct answer to "whether chromatic number problem is in NP?" is "we do not know".

Thanks, but I think this "any time" refers to hour -- i.e. with regular exam you have to be in class room at given hour, and work for X hours. Here, once exam is announced it lasts (AFAIR) 5 days, you can for example solve 2 questions, next day next 5 questions, and so on. I also checked the content of the exam, it is the same as 2 month ago.

title: Homework 1
body: Where does one find the posted answers? Thanks

In my opinion - moving to a system of education, independent of time would be a step in the right direction.

I understand that means that direct interaction of educators and students becomes difficult or impossible and preventing people from just looking directly at answers given elsewhere is going to be difficult, but Udacity are changing the way education is provided right?

My suggestion would be to make it so that people can learn at their own pace, according to their own schedule.

This means two major changes:

  1. Making answer videos available once the student has submitted their answers
  2. Designing homework question that have some variability so each individual's answer would be personal.

I'm sure that Udacity would argue that it makes it difficult to actually test whether people are just copying answers found from previous students, but it wouldn't be difficult to do that currently. There are already study groups forming by themselves, and anyway there's no certificate begin provided - we are basically on our honour that our answers are really our own effort.

If you understand Rajesh's explanation but still get that error, try looking for the following:

  1. Nested statements such as an if statement with a for inside of it, and an if inside of that. I occasionally misaligned a series of statements by a space or two and triggered the error. It's easy to miss when editing code you've already written.

  2. Look for an open paren or quotation without a corresponding closed paren/quotation.

title: How to store settings
body:
Hi there!

I 'm "expanding" a bit my blog app, and I came up with the necessity to save a set of values (namely my blog settings) in a place where they could be accessed from every Python module. I came up with the idea of creating a new GAE datastore called Data and save each value as a database tuple. The scheme of the entities looks like this:

class Data(db.Model):
    name = db.StringProperty(required=True)
    textvalue = db.StringProperty(required=False)
    intvalue = db.IntegerProperty(required=False)
    lastedit = db.DateTimeProperty(auto_add = True)

I plan to store there stuff like the number of posts per page I want in the homepage, the number of written posts (so I don't have to count them each time I need to) and so on.

I'd like to know your opinions on this. Is it a good practice to do such things? Or should I store the values some other way?

PD: Does my English sound strange? It's not my first language...

title: Can i use 'IF' in the homework 2 last Question
body:
Hello ,

Can i use 'IF' in the homework last Question (and question 8 too)

I posted some feedback which touched on this--I mentioned wanting to really work to be successful--but I'd like to expand on that a bit, here.

I studied math at uni, and if you'd say that a 'weeder course' is one that throws difficult material at students so they must either sink or swim, then nearly all of the classes I took were like this. And because I was able to 'swim', I very much liked the classes being that way, because they forced me to work hard and do my best, and as a result I learnt much more than if the course had moved more slowly in order to ensure that everyone learned the material equally.

Of course, if it were possible to teach the same amount of material, but have more students succeed, then I think that is certainly the right thing to do. But I'm not sure that's always possible. Or, where it is possible, I'm not sure that it's in general within the ability of the professors to do it.

For some online classes like Udacity offers, certainly people may continue trying and studying until they understand, but, realistically, not everyone is going to manage to do it within seven weeks, no matter how well explained or easy the material may be. There may be people who will struggle for seven weeks just trying to understand the first unit. And that's okay, because not everyone must learn at the same rate. But there is not such freedom if you are offering an in-person class at a university.

Basically, we must weigh the benefits of teaching a harder class vs. an easier class. Some people have said before me, here, that if the goal is to teach the most people the most knowledge, then weeding out any people at all is counterproductive. But if resources are scarce--teaching time, for example--then by weeding out a few of the worst performing students, all of the rest might benefit enough that it makes up for it. In a physical university, the people who are weeded out then must take a different class, maybe changing their major or perhaps they will even drop out altogether, and it's a shame, but it would be worse to serve everyone poorly than to serve most better and few poorly or not at all, I think. Certainly people are free to study on their own, but the universities must also limit the resources expended on each student.

The beauty of Udacity, though, is that it can offer classes of comparable difficulty to 'weeder' classes without needing to actually weed out any students. Even if a student is failing every homework assignment, they won't be forced out, and there's no incentive to force them out. So for online classes like this, the value calculus changes. Now you can just teach the best class possible, and continue to iterate until you serve better those who were poorly served at first, because the presence of poorly performing students doesn't hurt those who are performing well. People are free to continue to spend their time trying to learn for as long as they feel it's in their best interests.

So, I think that by all means Udacity should offer courses that are like weeder courses. Throw as much material as possible at students, and see what sticks. But also offer all the explanations and help that are needed to help everyone learn the material. Then, those who can learn the material more easily may continue to have lots of challenging material to study, and those who need more help may get it. And let the path through the course be chosen by the student. Already Udacity is like this--for those students who need no help with the homework, they may choose not to view the 'office hours' videos, and not to request help in the forums. For those who need more help, there are many avenues they may explore. If Udacity continues to build on this, then I think it may combine the best of both options. I hope that it does.

title: question 5 HW 2
body: i just wanna know if i can consider number "0" as a positive integer.. Thank You..

As shown in my example below, "the list" doesn't change. p simply points at a new list locally within that function. if you were to return p, you'd see this new list. however if you then refer to p again outside of the function, it is unchanged

code:

def proc2(p):
    p=p+[1]
    return p

p=[1,2,3]
print p .... returns [1,2,3]
print proc2(p) .... returns [1,2,3,1]
print p .... returns [1,2,3]

body:
I have the same issue. I will ultimately take them all, but this cycle I will go with the programming languages course because the technology is more fundamental. Understanding how the code we write is interpreted is basic to writing code in general.

I spent about a half a year in self-learning tutorial land before finding Udacity and still do a great deal of outside learning, and I find that knowing some of the lower level underpinnings of what's going on makes me feel more comfortable and confident with the high level useful stuff. Even though I don't know exactly how a given command is translated into machine instructions, having a basic idea of how the process works takes the mysticism out of what I am doing and helps my orientation.

I highly recommend this book: http://www.amazon.com/Assembly-Language-Step-Step-Programming/dp/0470497025/ref=dp_ob_title_bk

The book made me feel comfortable and confident learning any programming issue I come across. I also now appreciate how fortunate we are to be working with python type high level languages. The power is astounding. To use assembly to do the types of stuff we are doing in the homework would probably take thousands of lines of code.

This might be better as a comment than an answer, if so please forgive me. I cannot understand why in some examples there are splitlists with repeated characters. ie. ",.,.,.,.,. ". The splitlist is "a string containing all of the characters considered separators." I can see no reason of repeating them here.

Every Internet Service Providers (ISPs) own routers.... Any person or organisation can have his/her or their own router.... but the internet traffic we contribute to, wouldn't go through these personal routers unless we access data residing in their network. But the ISP routers traffic is mostly formed by the users/customers of their network service....I think yes, your government has its own routers in different departments.... NSA, DoD of US were very important force behind the development of today's networking system...

title: Interpreter not working
body: for some reason the interpreter is not working this morning.

If the rope were to break, it would be most likely to break at the bottom of the swing.

This deals with centripetal acceleration, which is a topic we didn't cover in class. To try to give you an intuitive feel for centripetal acceleration, let's say you are driving a car around a corner. When is it most likely to skid? Well, when you are going fast or when you are turning sharply. This skid out happens because friction can no longer provide the force necessary to keep you moving on your circular trajectory.

Moving in a circle (even at constant speed) is actually a form of acceleration. Remember, acceleration is changing velocity. Since velocity is a vector with both a size (speed) and a direction, you can actually have acceleration if all you are changing is your direction!

For a pendulum, your direction is changing most rapidly as it swings through the bottom. This corresponds to a big acceleration, and this requires a big force.

title: Performance of wheel resampling vs. "naive" resampling
body:
To compare the performance of wheel resampling vs. the naive method, I coded a quick script in Octave (sorry, was quicker than Python for me) to compare their performance, both in terms of accuracy of the distribution and of time.

--- edit ---
So finally I completely revamped the code to (1) remove some bugs and (2) compare more methods. So now the script reliably compares the performance of the following 4 methods:

  • Naive resampling: the simplest and least performing method (in O(n^2))
  • Naive Binary-search: for each i=1..N, the search is now done with a binary search (complexity is now O(n.log(n))
  • Wheel: Sebastian's method
  • Wheel-modified: here, index is initialized at 1 and 2*omega_max is replaced by 2/N

Performance is measured according to 3 types of metrics:

  • Distances: there are 3 of them (1) Sum (A(i) - B(i))^2 ; (2) Sum A(i)*|A(i)-B(i)| ; (3) Kullback divergence(A,B)
  • Miss rate: the %age of particles that have not survived to the resampling, despite having a >0 importance weight
  • Time

Here is the output for N=5000 particles:

Omega          |         N |  N * mean | N * stDev |   N * min |   N * max 
               :      5000 |  1.000000 |  1.014080 |  0.000016 |  9.311148    
Error   \ Algo |     Naive |  N-binary |     Wheel | Wheel-mod 
Squared        :  3.82e-08 |  3.88e-08 |  3.68e-08 |  2.16e-08
Exp |error|    :  2.09e-04 |  2.13e-04 |  2.05e-04 |  1.47e-04
Kullback div   :  4.81e-01 |  4.90e-01 |  4.70e-01 |  3.33e-01
Freq. misses   :       49% |       50% |       49% |       43%
Time           :  1.12e+02 |  1.45e+00 |  1.49e+00 |  3.80e-01

Conclusion: Sebastian's wheel method seems to perform quite similarly to the Naive-Binary method (which is confirmed by repeating the experience a good many times).
Conclusion 2: The modified wheel resampler seems to perform a bit better than the original version: distance with the original omega is lower, it "misses" fewer particles (on average 5% less) and is much quicker.

To better understand the meaning of the metrics, I killed the Naive method (too slow) and added a null sampler which simply produces the initial sample (ie the re-sampler distribution is uniform over the initial particle set) ; this should give, for all 3 distance metrics, a view of what a very poor sampling method does. Here is the outcome for N=50,000:

Omega          |         N |  N * mean | N * stDev |   N * min |   N * max 
               :     50000 |  1.000000 |  1.003655 |  0.000031 | 12.279639
Error   \ Algo |  N-binary |     Wheel | Wheel-mod | Unif-test 
Squared        :  3.96e-10 |  3.69e-10 |  2.11e-10 |  4.03e-10
Exp |error|    :  2.11e-05 |  2.02e-05 |  1.45e-05 |  2.43e-05
Kullback div   :  4.88e-01 |  4.71e-01 |  3.25e-01 |  3.36e-01
Freq. misses   :       50% |       49% |       43% |        0%
Time           :  1.77e+01 |  1.88e+01 |  3.77e+00 |  8.52e-04

Again, the modified wheel resampler seems to perform better than the original one from all standpoints.

Finally, I ran the same tests with values for the step that replaces Sebastian's 2*omega_max : alpha/N for alpha=0.5,1,2,3,etc. Clearly, 2/N yields the best performance (best distance and best miss rate) of all tested values. Below is the script's output for alpha=0.5, 1, 2, 4:

Omega          |         N |  N * mean | N * stDev |   N * min |   N * max 
               :     25000 |  1.000000 |  0.998683 |  0.000033 | 10.983644
Error  \ Alpha |  0.5      |  1        |  2        |  4 
Squared        :  1.01e-08 |  3.93e-09 |  8.42e-10 |  1.04e-09
Exp |error|    :  1.19e-04 |  8.16e-05 |  2.87e-05 |  3.24e-05
Kullback div   :  1.42e+00 |  9.24e-01 |  3.25e-01 |  3.93e-01
Freq. misses   :       78% |       63% |       43% |       46%
Time           :  1.61e+00 |  1.76e+00 |  2.14e+00 |  2.84e+00

Here is the code:

## Octave/Matlab script to compare 'naive', 'naive-binary' and wheel resamplers
# N    = 1000;                   # number of particles
nbAlgo = 4;                      # number of algos tested
sample = zeros(nbAlgo, N);       # row(i) will contain sample for algo #i
time   = zeros(1, nbAlgo);       # time(i) will contain execution time for algo #i
omega  = -log(rand(1,N));        # N-sized vector; each omega(i) ~ Exp(1) law
# omega = ones(1,N)/N;           # used as control; each omega(i) = 1/N
omega  = omega/sum(omega);       # normalization
Omega  = ones(nbAlgo,1)*omega;   # omega copied over nbAlgo rows

## Algo 1 --- Naive sampler ---
algo = 1;                        # for referencing
tic();                           # start timer
for i=1:N
  r = rand();
  j = 1; 
  s = omega(j);
  while (r>s)
    j += 1;
    s += omega(j);
  endwhile
  sample(algo,i) = j;
endfor
time(algo) = toc();               # stop timer

## Algo 2 --- Naive Binary-search sampler ---
algo += 1;
tic();
sumOmega = cumsum(omega);        # vector of cumulative sums
for i=1:N
  r  = rand();
  lo = 0;
  hi = N;
  while (hi-lo >= 2)
    mid  = floor((lo+hi)/2);
    if r > sumOmega(mid)
      lo = mid;
    else
      hi = mid;
    endif
  endwhile
  sample(algo,i) = lo+1;
endfor
time(algo) = toc();

## Algo 3 --- Wheel sampler ---
algo += 1;
tic(); 
omegaMax = max(omega);
j        = ceil(rand()*N);
beta     = 0;
for i=1:N
  beta = mod(beta + rand()*2*omegaMax, 1);
  while (omega(j) < beta)
    beta -= omega(j);
    j = mod(j,N)+1;
  endwhile
  sample(algo,i) = j;
endfor
time(algo) = toc();

## Algo 4 --- Modified wheel sampler ---
algo += 1;
tic(); 
j    = 1;            # j is initialized at 1
beta = 0;
for i=1:N
  beta = mod(beta + rand()*2/N, 1); # 2*omegaMax is replaced by 2/N
  while (omega(j) < beta)
    beta -= omega(j);
    j     = mod(j,N)+1;
  endwhile
  sample(algo,i) = j;
endfor
time(algo) = toc();

## --------------------
## Performance analysis
## --------------------

distribution = zeros(nbAlgo,N);
for i=1:N
  distribution(:,i) = sum(sample==i,2)/N;
endfor
# distribution(algo,i) = frequency of value i in sample(algo)

error = distribution - Omega;
# error(algo,i) = distribution(algo,i) - omega(i)

expErr = sum(Omega .* abs(error),2);
# expErr(algo) = sum of omega(i)*abs(error(algo,i))

relativeErr = error ./ Omega;
# relativeErr(algo,i) = (distribution(algo,i) - omega(i))/omega(i)

squareErr = sumsq(error,2)/N;
# squareErr(algo) = sum of error(algo,i)^2 / N

freqMiss = sum(distribution==0,2)/N;
# freqMiss(algo) = %age of particles "missed" by algo

t = 0.1; Q = (1-t)*distribution + t*Omega;
Kullback = sum(Omega .* log(Omega ./ Q),2);

## ------
## Output
## ------

printf("Omega          | %9s | %9s | %9s | %9s | %9s \n", "N", "N * mean", "N * stDev", "N * min", "N * max");
printf("               : %9i | %9f | %9f | %9f | %9f\n", N, N*mean(omega), N*std(omega), N*min(omega), N*max(omega));
printf("\n");
printf("Error   \\ Algo | %9s | %9s | %9s | %9s \n", "Naive", "N-binary", "Wheel", "Wheel-mod");
printf("Squared        : %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e\n", squareErr(:));
printf("Exp |error|    : %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e\n", expErr(:));
printf("Kullback div   : %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e\n", Kullback(:));
printf("Freq. misses   : %8i%% | %8i%% | %8i%% | %8i%%\n", 100*freqMiss(:));
printf("Time           : %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e | %9.2e\n", time(:));
printf("\n");

title: members from Bangladesh
body: who are from Bangladesh??

This has been asked several times.
.5 rounds up

I'm taking all three. This class really hasn't required a huge time commitment, so I think I can handle it. If not, so what? They're free classes from a free online university. I'm not exactly worried about my "GPA".

I've got a job, wife, and kids. Udacity is my fun hobby!

I have also looked at several environments over the past couple weeks. I didn't want the huge bloat of spme of the full IDEs, and I didn't want a commercial product (I want it to be cheap! :D). This is what I found so far:

If you want really basic (but better than just the python command) use notepad++ and the python plugins. This is what I use the most actually!

You could try the open source Komodo as suggested other places, but its quite big and slow to startup.

The best balance between agility and functionality seems to be PyScripter its open source and quite good and its my favourite at the moment.

Thanks for sharing your knowledge, @Ken. I hope you still hang around even though you've finished the final exam. There are lots people that are still going through the lectures and that would benefit from your expertize. :)

title: What is the impact Udacity will have on the online teaching world?
body:
After crawling the web trying to answer this question (for myself) I stumbled upon this recent article which pretty much sum-sup the power of Udacity.
Enjoy!
How Udacity's Greatest Effect ...

How do you think Udacity will impact your learning experience, in and outside institutional walls and into the web?

What I'll probably do is take some time to read a few books. I've fallen way behind my usual [slow] pace. One can get a great education from books -- too bad they don't also provide a social life. (Wes found a way to work them in, though, in CS262. :-)

I also need to get my used book business ramped up. (Last week I sold a leather-bound Batman commemorative edition for $125!) My software for working with book data needs a lot of work, especially the parts for analyzing online listings. (If I get far enough with it, maybe I'll turn it into a Udacity course. That will take at least a decade, though.)

And I have yet to start on my dream of analyzing recipes in some of my cookbooks. (What is the "space" of all good chile recipes? How does it differ from that of other stews? What can I say about salad dressings, or puddings? What are good minimal pantries for various home cuisines?)

Or I could get back to my stalled project on mapping color names to regions in analytic color spaces.

And of course there's the Internet to explore. And new programming languages to learn. And far too many online courses I could take. There's just too much to do! The more I know, the less I find this Life Sucks cartoon relevant. Have a good life, everyone!

title: Brainstorming ideas for the contest and course summary
body:
I imagine a lot of people will want to keep their ideas secret but if you're like me and don't really know where to start, this is a place to toss ideas around or organize your thoughts

The judging criteria is creativity and relevance. I find it's much easier to be creative once you have a structure that you can play with, so I'll try to tackle "relevance" part of the contest. To do that we're going to need a summary of the course, which incidentally might also be very useful for the final. This isn't a complete list, but I think it's cool to have something to refer to remind us of what was learned.

Unit 1

  • Variables
  • Strings - Selecting, Searching, Indexing

Purpose in the Search Engine: To be able to recognize and extract hyperlinks

Unit 2

  • Procedures
  • Comparisons
  • if statements
  • while loops

Purpose in the Search Engine: To be able to run hyperlink extraction process many times automatically

Unit 3

  • Lists
  • Nested lists
  • Modifying a list and mutation
  • For loops and iteration

Purpose in the Search Engine: Finishing link extraction and having a place to put them all

Unit 4

  • Data structures
  • How the internet works

Purpose in the Search Engine: It's just good to know.

Unit 5

  • Runtime analysis
  • Hash table and functions
  • Mod operator
  • Dictionaries

Purpose in the Search Engine: Making it faster and more responsive

Unit 6

  • Recursion
  • Graphs

Purpose in the Search Engine: Ranking results

Other random stuff that found its way into lectures/homework

  • Three Stooges
  • Grace Hopper
  • Smoke signals
  • Horny bunnies
  • Sudoku
  • Collatz Conjecture

Summary of all the specific python stuff learned: link

So I'm realizing that this is really a very broad range of topics. Knowing basic data structures and control flow, there's a lot of directions. One thing that came to mind was a sudoku solver, which is boring, but not a trivial problem either. The most intuitive thing might be to adapt the web crawler into something more efficient or maybe to find things other than links. Or maybe a really simple cryptography exercise in using hash tables to encode and decode messages.

One thing that I now noticed wasn't covered cause of the way assignments had to be accepted is getting user input. In python it's really simple, if you type out

name = raw_input("Enter your name: ")

the user will be prompted for input and it'll automatically be stored in the variable name.

Kudos to you if you managed to read all the way to this line.

Bon cours !

Joachim, yours is clear, concise code, but it is not computing the right thing here.
Your result is something similar to the arithmetic mean (the sum of all elements divided by how many they are).

The median is different, it's the number in the middle, out of the three given numbers (it is used, for example, in some statistics, to estimate the average of something very quickly, without much computing=,

So your code needs to look for the one number out of the three that isn't the biggest nor the smallest.

By the way, the median of, say, five, or any other odd number of numbers is also the number in a middle. If the number of numbers is even, say 6, the median is the arithmetic mean of the middle two. (Hope this is all correct, I only learnt all this recently, too).

title: Office Hours Posted
body: Office Hours Posted under Course Content.

Why aren't more people using Lisp? Well, I'd give a couple of reasons.

First, out of habit (er, well, it could be argued that the next two-three ones are also about habit. Oh well). Lisp traditionally was a academic, AI-research language, used where computer resources were less controlled than in the industry. "A Lisp programmer knows the value of everything and the cost of nothing", and all that. Lisp systems could afford to waste cycles and memory, since for the AI researchers, the benefit and pure power of expression was the thing. In the industry, computers were used for mundane, repetitive tasks. Lisps expressive power was not needed, and it was too expensive in machine resources. Nowadays, those things are no longer relevant (the Lisp compilers are heaps better, the resources are plentiful, etc) but "Real systems programming" is still using languages from the legacy that came from Algol - Pascal - C - C++ and so on. Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM - That kind of thing

Secondly, because writing Lisp is Different(tm). Most computer languages give you a set of blocks, and programming is a matter of putting those blocks together to solve your problem. It is conceptually a bounded environment. Lisp gives you the tools to build your own blocks, and the problem rather becomes one of deciding what blocks would be useful to solve this problem, and then inventing them. What Kilaws talks about when he (?) talks about Lisp being a language to build languages in. It is of course possible to write Lisp programs that mirror more conventional programming styles, but to get to the power of the language, this is where you need to go. And that is a very different way of thinking. The language that is most similar to this style, I think, is Forth.

Thirdly, because the work environment is different. Lisp is (these days) usually programmed interactively and interpreted - A bit like Python, if you use something like IDLE, where you write your code file in one window and test it out at the Python prompt. Only, in Lisp you can do everything from there. You start off writing a few functions to try things out, write a few test cases. Crash out, and interactively debug your code (inspecting variable values at the crash site, back up or go forward, change a function definition in the running program and continue) Identify some common patterns that you abstract into a macro. Load a profiling package that you've written earlier and attach it to your already written functions. Find out that most of the time is spent in two particular functions, so you compile them to get a bit of performance boost. And so on. The functions you've written, the debugger, the compiler - Everything is at your fingers, interactively, at the prompt. This is also very different, if you're used to the write-compile-test cycle with an external debugger, a compiler that compiles all or nothing, and so on.

Fourthly, because Lisp has so long been a part of academia, there hasn't really been development in the directions that other languages went. A general use language these days has a large standard library, access to GUI tools, stuff like that. It took a long time for Lisp to get these things (insofar as it still has them), because, well...academics... :D The situation is better today, but for a long time it has been behind in the glitz'n'gui departments.

Fifthly (is that even a word?), there is the heretical thought that maybe, just maybe, that power and expressivity isn't all that important in the real world, really. I shudder to write it down, but maybe it isn't really that good? Oh, who am I trying to fool - Of course it is :-)

I think that while everyone DOES solve programs differently, and VERY good programmers solve them in very unique and elegant ways, there IS something to the idea of learning to think like a programmer.

For example, right now there is a thread concerning HW 4.5, our "Better Splitter" HW assignment. You can very clearly identify the difference in thinking in the main issue this thread is concerned about:

Namely, is the SPACE considered a special character? Well, to humans (and non-programmers ;) the space IS special because it represents the LACK of something. But the programmer realizes this is an illusion and that to the COMPUTER, there is no difference other than in a bit pattern. IOW, the COMPUTER simply "sees" a space as ANOTHER character (and so does the programmer) but a non-programmer thinks of a space as something being missing.

This is a VERY simple example, but if you go with it for awhile, you'll see that there are literally millions of little things like this that a non-programmer wouldn't consider, but a programmer does. An experienced programmer will not be fooled by these little "gotchas" and edge cases and such because she's SEEN them before...she DOES think differently than a non-programmer.

The code we wrote also took a keyword as input. 

def record_user_click(index,keyword,url):

We updated the click count only for the url with that keyword. This is similar to you going to google, searching for Udacity. If you click on the Udacity website, then the count for www.udacity.com should only be increased with reference to that one keyword, not for every such instance.

Click data is generally harvested by search engines for the purpose of ranking urls for keywords.

If you have no experience in programming in general, and Python in particular, I suggest you go for cs101 instead for now (there is still time to complete hw2, even if you haven't started yet). That will give you a gentle introduction in Python and set you up for the future courses that will start in April (info from Office hours 2).

Also, it helps to have a development environment set up and editing, debugging and saving your code locally. There is wide array of options for that, depending on your preferences. This is a good read about IDE options: good-python-ide.

You might want to look also in this thread: any-free-book-for-phyton

If I remember correctly, they were actually using the heat generated by the human body as an energy source. This is possible, but incredibly stupid. Yes, the human body does generate heat. Yes, that heat could be used as a source of energy. But in order to generate heat, the body must be supplied energy (food), and the amount of energy in that food will always be greater than the amount that could be gained from using the heat produced. The aliens should have just used whatever they were feeding the humans as their energy source. Unless I'm forgetting part of the movie.

As to what you said: Charge does flow in our bodies. Small electric fields are created in our bodies. There is energy in these fields. But to create these fields we need to expend more energy than we could reclaim from the field.

Energy transformations are inefficient. The human body is particularly bad. When we want to get some energy from somewhere, we want to transform that energy as few times as possible.

For example, think back to unit 4. A windmill can be used to do mechanical work (like lifting water out of the Netherlands) or it can be used to generate electrical power, which can THEN be converted to mechanical energy. This second option is less efficient than the first, since some energy is "lost" to heat in the transformation from mechanical energy (the spinning windmill) to electric energy and then more is lost in the transformation from electric back to mechanical (the turning screw).

Long story short: the matrix is a great movie built on a ridiculous premise. Great question.

EDIT: Jonathan has informed me that the bad guys in the Matrix are machines not aliens. I apologize for my amateur mistake.

It depends on how you count the time.

In my case, if I am thinking about a quiz or homework problem I am stuck on I would include that (I'm an obsessive thinker and an unsolved problem won't drift far from my thoughts even when I'm focused on something else). So, that can be as many as 10 - 12 hours/week just thinking about problems that need to be solved to complete the assignment or how to improve a solution I've already developed.

If I include actual time watching the videos, then that is an additional 5 - 10 hrs/week depending on how many repeat viewings.

So, the range would be 15 - 22hrs/week. Most of my free time is after the kids go to bed and on the weekends. I usually go to bed around midnight.

I grew interested in programming after tiring of making Arduino micro controllers blink LEDs or record temperatures etc. It turned out I found the programming more interesting than the actual physical results (although programming a micro controller really forces you to manage your resources carefully since the memory and whatnot is so limited).

What about doing the very same sense and move function all over again and again, just doing it very fast? (E.g. Sebastian mentioned in the video that the laser sensor on the car's roof is taking scans 10 times a second.)

If you think about it, that is precisely what you do, when you are driving your car. You look at the road in front of you and you see a pedestrian coming in your way (sense). It takes few hundreds miliseconds for your brain to process that information and send a signal to your leg in order to push a break pedal (move - just a "zero move").

title: Typo in the Announcements: Office(r) Hours 1
body:
The first Office Hours have been posted. But the Announcements page has 'Officer Hours 1' (sic) as title of the post announcing this.

Yes Officer!

Thanks so much for these insights, Anne. Very helpful indeed!

With regard to SVM, it seems that was the framework in which the Kalman filter was developed and introduced. However, the more modern context is that of Bayes Networks, where the Kalman Filter is a special case of a Dynamic Bayes Network (DBN). See for example Probabilistic Graphical Models by Koller and Friedman. Of course having multiple viewpoints is always a good thing.

Thanks again for all your hard work.

H projects (i.e. extracts) the observable components of the state vector into the observed vector. In the examples it just extracts x and y from the state (x,x_dot,y,y_dot), this is something that we know before hand so it need not be made into an input of the filter function, it is just a constant.

R is the amount of noise of the measurement. We just estimate it and leave it like constant.

Finally I is the identity matrix (one along the diagonal zeros on the rest of positions), it is part of the algorithm and it is the always like that independetly of the filter (except for dimensionality which depends on the problem solved)
The homework assignments helped embed the logic behind kalman filters,Particle Filters, histogram filters right into my brain ..the effort to reward ratio is awesome..

The simplest way would be with default argument values.

def foo (bar = 1):
    return bar

foo(2) # returns 2

foo()  #returns 1

This is a really good question Aman.

A large part of the beauty of physics lies in its predictive power. Prediction means calculation. So any good physics course does need to have calculations involved.

But I don't think that rigorous calculations are the best way to be exposed to material for the first time. Thought-provoking questions that allow you to reconcile your innate understanding of the world with the language of math and physics are much more productive in my opinion.

So, yes. A physics class MUST have calculation, but it shouldn't be entirely calculation-based.

In the old days, in London or New York, the gentlemen's clubs were very powerful social organizations. Those inside -- even if just the nephew of a member -- had powerful advantages over anyone on the outside, no matter what their personal qualities or skills.

Ivy League and world-class universities have functioned in much the same way, though sometimes more subtly. Success in business has often been a matter of who you know rather than what you know. Mere technical mastery would relegate you to the working class.

Entrepreneurship has offered a way to leapfrog into the upper ranks, at least to the extent that the nouveau riche can ever do so. And computer science has offered a new and easy path to entrepreneurship, for those with chutzpah and entrepreneurial spirit. Now Udacity and the like are offering an easy path into computer science.

But is that enough to compete with what one finds at Stanford? In theory, yes. In practice, I think the answer is "seldom." To put it rather crudely, you can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear -- nor can you make an entrepreneur out of a computer geek (Bill Gates excepted). Stanford is in the business of screening out all but the most likely students to succeed, then nurturing them in an environment that demands initiative and expects success. Some few of those graduates will go on to make major contributions to the endowment fund; hopefully the rest will have useful and satisfying lives.

Udacity certainly has the power to put isolated students on a path to greatness. (For that matter, so does the Internet. Or books. Or a wealthy patron. Or one good teacher.) But for typical cases, online education lacks some important elements.

First is the screening. Large universities use their introductory chemistry classes (or some other difficult course) to weed out the weak, from a student body that was carefully selected to begin with from valedictorians and high school/prep school leaders. Udacity's CS101 has likewise whittled us down to perhaps as few a 100 students, judging from forum page views, but starting from a less-screened pool. Yes, Udacity has worldwide reach, and hence will tap brilliance and expertise beyond Stanford's reach. But still, the output of an online education will typically resemble the input of a Stanford education.

Second is the poor teaching often found at a large research university. As grateful as we are for Dave's good instruction, let's recognize that Udacity is spoonfeeding us. A short lecture, an easy quiz, a short test, all with feedback as to the right way to work the problems. Step by step, we are lead to a packaged conclusion. It is as if the instructor pulled out a favorite piece of code and spent the next seven weeks stepping us through the modules and statements and concepts. Yes, it is educational, but in the end we learn only a little beyond that one piece of code. Any school has to do much the same, but most will require far more book reading and lab work. Further, bad teaching encourages independent student effort. Students band into study groups for survival, and must sometimes prepare themselves for the final exam almost in spite of the instructor's efforts to draw them into his/her own research specialty. The dynamics are complex and different for each class and student, but tend to inculcate social and educational skills you won't get from Udacity forums.

As @charlzz mentioned, there is also the issue of living at home instead of in a dorm. My father was a professor, so I lived at home as an undergraduate. It was a mistake. I needed the experience of living with others of my own age and circumstances. Not being social, I had little contact with other students outside class. I remained a nerd. And my grades suffered as well, though as an individual I was smart enough. I like to think that I have turned out well, but I know that my poor socialization (originating in grade school and unrecognized ADHD) put me on the wrong path. I wonder if Udacity isn't offering the same to most of its students.

title: How do I access answers in Discussion
body: I'm unable to figure out how to find answers to questions listed in discussion. How does this work?

I think in Layman's terms you could simply say that you have a robot in a room, and it has a map of the room, but it doesn't know where it is in this room. So to the robot, it believes it could be anywhere in the room, so it places a particle in each possible position. Now as it starts to move and senses, it is sure is not in some places, so those particles die out, while the probability for other places increases, so the particles increase in size.

And then the filter iterates until it finds out where it is.

As Michel said, gravity propagates at the speed of light. I did a bit of research as an undergraduate in gravitational waves. Einstein's theory predicts that when mass accelerates in the right way, it will actually cause space to ripple. These ripples will stretch objects in one direction and compress them in the perpendicular direction.

These waves are so tiny that they require massive L-shaped observatories (like LIGO) to detect them. My job was to look at events that triggered LIGO into thinking that it had seen a gravitational wave. Nine times out of ten, the cause was a train passing. The rumbling from the tracks was enough to move LIGO's mirrors and cause a false positive.

def factorial(n):
if n == 0:

elif n == 1:
    return 1
else:
    return n*factorial(n-1)

title: unit 4 q 16
body: wont let me give my bandwidth. says its wrong?

I'll add another thing: don't be fooled by "inefficiency": this is the theory, and as such is... I'll call it "plain and complete". Usually inverting a matrix can be a cumbersome task if done by hand, but consider that a normal PC will invert a non-sparse matrix of a thousand rows and colums in few milliseconds. Moreover, since the properties of the matrix (i.e. the fact that it is very sparse and that the position of non-zero elements) are well known, it is possible to write very efficient inversion algorithms that will perform only the necessary calculations. You could write an "inverse_sparse_xy" method that will correctly operate on the known matrix structure and you'd get back to very efficient. But again, this that is presented here is the theory, and the theory is at a general level, where simly mu = Omega' * Xi... easier this way, and as @MCN quoted, it's better for the robots

I used recursion too:

def plan(road, lane_change_cost, init, goal): 
    lanes = len(road)

    def get_cost(lane, velocity, next_costs):
        if velocity == 0:
            return float('inf')

        go_left = next_costs[lane - 1] if lane > 0 else float('inf')
        go_ahead = next_costs[lane]
        go_right = next_costs[lane + 1] if lane + 1 < lanes else float('inf')

        next_cost = min([go_left + lane_change_cost, go_ahead, go_right + lane_change_cost])
        return 1./velocity + next_cost

    def get_costs(segment):
        costs = [float('inf')] * lanes
        if segment == goal[1]:
            costs[goal[0]] = 0
        else:
            next_costs = get_costs(segment + 1)
            for lane in range(lanes):
                velocity = road[lane][segment]
                costs[lane] = get_cost(lane, velocity, next_costs)
        return costs

    costs = get_costs(init[1])
    return costs[init[0]]

When it comes to filtering discussion topics, there are a number of quick options for ordering the results. Most popular, Most active, etc.
a) These go away when you are in an individual topic. Too bad, since some discussions get lengthy indeed.
b) Those sort options could benefit significantly by having an additional option to apply a time frame (or even exponentially declining weight by time since posting). A generally appealing topic that hangs around for a while will begin to outrank even hot questions posted in the last day, since many more people will see the long-term winners, but fewer people will respond to topics related to an individual unit or hw problem.

So, filtering by recency before applying other filters could improve sorting/searching for relevant info.

title: User Generated Challenges
body:
A lot of students have been asking for additional programming challenges to accompany the homework. The Udacity team is plenty busy with developing the course content we have, so it will be a good idea for the participants of CS101 to create some challenging problems on our own. This thread is for collecting those challenges for students to try to improve their skills between units and homework assignments. Post an answer below if you have a challenge to submit for this thread and I will keep updating the list.

THE LIST

  1. Write a procedure that takes a string of words as an input ("banana garage door elephant") and returns the same list of words as a string in alphabetical order ("banana door elephant garage").

  2. Using the tools covered in Unit One, write a program extracting the First sentence of a given Wikipedia entry (the source of the webpage is assigned to a string) and print it. (From this thread by @Bf5man)

  3. Using only the tools available in Unit 1, write Python code that will output the length of a given string. Submitted by @Tutan_ka

  4. Write a program that converts a base-10 integer to hexadecimal(base-16). Submitted by @KenavR
    (Bonus: Write a program that converts from any starting base to any target base. By @forbiddenvoid)

  5. You learned how to calculate the factorial of a number in unit two. Now make a define a function that calculates the factorial of a number using recursion. By @elssar

  6. Make two functions - one to generate the fibonacci sequence upto the n'th number. Another to calculate the n'th fibonacci number. Research into Binet's Formula(search yourself) for calculating the n'th Fibonacci number & try making your functions using that formula. By @elssar

  7. Define a function to find if a number is a palindrome. Now define a recursive function to find whether a number is a palindrome. Can you make a palindrome function for strings? By @elssar

  8. Using only the tools from Units 1 and 2, write Python functions to perform arbitrary precision floating point math where the numbers are stored as strings. I think that this is doable for {+, -, *}. Bonus - support negative numbers. Bonus - support scientific notation. Superstar - figure out some compromise for division. By @KeithE

  9. Building on the last homework question in unit 3, write a program that will verify whether a solved 9x9 Sudoku square is correct. That means 1) All digits 1-9 in each row, column and all 9 3x3 sections of the square. If you decide to work on this, do not post any solutions until after the homework three deadline, because it could give away code for that homework. by @forbiddenvoid

  10. Implement the Sieve of Eratosthenes to find prime numbers between 1 & n, and also to check whether a number is prime or not. By @elssar

  11. Given any Integer, print all prime numbers that add up to the integer. by @Algoribinna

  12. Write a function, that takes as input a positive integer n & produces a spiral matrix of size n - 2 Stars. by @elssar

title: Am I stupid?
body: My IQ is high enough but I'm not following this. Is there a remedial class one can take to understand the basics so I might comprehend this introduction to programming?

Dear Ken,

Prof Thrun's and my computation for unit31-5 is as follows :-

Priors probabilities P(T=1)=P(T=2)=P(T=3)=1/3

Here P(T=k) (for k=1,2,3) denote the probability of the True location of the car.

The joint probability P(M=3,T=1)=1/3 (computed as 1/3 * 1), P(M=3,T=2)=1/6 ( computed as 1/3 *1/2) , P(M=3,T=3)=0 ( computed as 1/3 * 0). Here we use the independence of 2 events to multiply their probability. Also we assume the player chooses door 2.

The likelihood, P(M=3|T=1)=P(M=3,T=1)/P(T=1)=(1/3)/(1/3)=1

P(T=1|M=3)=P(T=1,M=3)/P(M=3)

We first compute, P(M=3) = P(M=3|T=1)P(T=1) + P(M=3|T=2)P(T=2) + P(M=3|T=3)P(T=3) = P(M=3,T=1)+P(M=3,T=2)+P(M=3,T=2) = 1/3 + 1/6 + 0 = 1/2 ( this is what I think Prof. Thrun is computing).

Hence
P(T=1|M=3) = P(M=3,T=1)/P(M=3) = (1/3)/(1/2) = 2/3
P(T=2|M=3) = P(M=3,T=2)/P(M=3) = (1/6)/(1/2) = 1/3
P(T=3|M=3) = P(M=3,T=3)/P(M=3) = 0/(1/2) = 0

My computation,using Baye's Rule is like this:-

Prior Probabilities are as above.
Likelihood probabilities:-
P(M=3|T=1) = 1
P(M=3|T=2) = 1/2
P(M=3|T=3) = 0
The above is conditional to the player choosing door 2.
Now we want the Posterior distributions,P(T=k|M=3),k=1,2,3.

P(T=k|M=3) = P(M=3|T=k)P(T=k)/P(M=3) for k=1,2,3. ---(i)

P(M=3)=P(M=3|T=1)P(T=1)+P(M=3|T=2)P(T=2)+P(M=3|T=3)P(T=3)=1.(1/3)+(1/2).(1/3) + 0.(1/3) = 1/2

Hence,by using (i),

P(T=1|M=3)=1.(1/3) / (1/2) = 2/3
P(T=2|M=3)=(1/2)(1/3) / (1/2)=1/3

Now that I typed it out I think both the methods are the same. I would love to hear anyone's thought's on this. To me, Prof Thrun's quick method of dividing by the sum was not obvious,but now I think even he is simply using Baye's Rule. Do I misunderstand ?

Do you know what factorial in math is? If you do, you should know that you want a product of consecutive numbers, starting from 1 to n (the given input to factorial). result holds that product. n is also a counter (that is decreased by 1 every time the next number is multiplied to result) so the while loop knows when to stop multiplying numbers to result.

But the result you want from the factorial function is result, not n (which will be 0 no matter what the input is).

Bambus, I think this was probably confusing you because Dave started talking about using return vs. break before he finished writing all of the code for the procedure. With only the code he had written at around 2:10, when he started talking about return vs. break, using return either of them would have functioned essentially the same, in that the procedure would end right there, because there was nothing after the loop.

However, Dave was about to add more code after that loop in order to address the case that keyword wasn't found in index. If he HAD used break instead of return, that index.append([keyword, [url]]) line after the for-loop would have been executed even when the keyword WAS found, which would give a duplicate keyword entry in index.

Hope that helps!

thanks ;) :)

scheme implementation

this is my second version which is a bit longer than the original, but handles arbitrarily nested structures through use of enumerated

(define (transpose . l) (apply map list l))
(define (partial f . a) (lambda x (apply f (append a x))))
(define (flatten lst)
  (cond ((null? lst) '())
        ((list? lst) 
         (append 
           (flatten (car lst))
           (flatten (cdr lst))))
        (else (list lst))))
(define (foldl f a lst)
  (if (null? lst) a
    (foldl f (f a (car lst)) (cdr lst))))
(define dimensional-ref (partial foldl list-ref))
(define (range n)
  (let loop ((start 0) (r '()))
    (if (>= start n)
      (reverse r)
      (loop (+ start 1) (cons start r)))))

(define (enumerated p f)
  (define (inner c e i)
    (if (list? e)
      (map 
        (partial apply inner (cons i c))
        (transpose e (range (length e))))
      (f (reverse (cons i c)))))
  (map 
    (partial apply inner '())
    (transpose p (range (length p)))))

(define (normalize p)
  (define (sub indices)
    (/ (dimensional-ref p indices) 
       (apply + (flatten p))))
  (enumerated p sub))

(define colors
  '((r g g r r)
    (r r g r r)
    (r r g g r)
    (r r r r r)))
(define measures
  '(g g g g g))
(define motions
  '((0 0)
    (0 1)
    (1 0)
    (1 0)
    (0 1)))
(define sensor_right 7/10)
(define p_move 4/5)
(define p (normalize (enumerated colors (lambda x 1))))

(define (sense p Z)
  (define (hit? indices)
    (* (if (eq? Z (dimensional-ref colors indices))
         sensor_right
         (- 1 sensor_right))
       (dimensional-ref p indices)))
  (normalize (enumerated p hit?)))

(define (move p d-indices)
  (define (move-each indices)
    (define (access parent di i)
      (list-ref parent (modulo (- i di) (length parent))))
    (+ (* p_move 
          (foldl (partial apply access) p (transpose d-indices indices)))
       (* (- 1 p_move) (dimensional-ref p indices))))
  (normalize (enumerated p move-each)))

(define (step p motion measure)
  (sense (move p motion) measure))

(foldl (partial apply step) p (transpose motions measures))

title: [Resource] [Wiki] Recommended reading - awesome blog posts to knock your socks off!
body:
Over the years I've come across various great posts on the internet related to programming. A lot of those I consider essential reading for programmers. So I shall be sharing a list of blog posts over here, some essential, some not(but still good reads).

  1. Learning to Code: The Roadmap I Wish I Had Been Given - Just read this one today. More relevant to beginners with no or very little programming background.
  2. How I Became a Programmer - A post in the same vein as the first one.
  3. Why can't Programmers... Program? - On the importance of knowing the little things, by Jeff Atwood, cofounder of StackExchange, the model for the Q&A framework the Udacity Forums uses.
  4. Recursion Explained with the Flood Fill Algorithm (and Zombies and Cats), a very good explanation of Recursion by Al Sweigart, the writer of Invent Your own Computer Games with Python.
  5. Principles of Good Programming
  6. Teach Yourself Programming in 10 Years, by Peter Norvig - MUST READ
  7. Become a Good Programmer in Six Really Hard Steps, a good follow up on the Peter Norvig post MUST READ
  8. How to RTFM - Tips for a life of discovery - Stuck at a problem? Solution - search google(or ask on the forums). No! That's the worst you could do. Read The F---ing Manual! (:P)
  9. Demise of the Low Level Programmer - For people who really want to get into serious programming
  10. 10 Rules of a Zen Programmer
  11. Knuth : Programming as an Art - Yes, it's art
  12. A Visual Guide to Version Control - If you stick to programming for more than a while, then you're eventually going to end up using(if you don't, then you should) Version control. So better learn about it sooner rather than later.
  13. The true Fathers of Computing - A little history lesson.
  14. How to Write Without Writing - Jeff Atwood again, on the importance of writing(having good communication skills) for a programmer
  15. Evolutionary Algorithm : Evolving "Hello, World!" - Probably the one post which is most off topic here, but I just love this it.
  16. Signs that you are a bad Programmer - Catch 'em early, better than finding out later or even worse never finding out, and fix them.
  17. The Jargon File - It's not a blog post, but still an important resource. From Chapter 1 - Introduction : This document is a collection of slang terms used by various subcultures of computer hackers. Though some technical material is included for background and flavor, it is not a technical dictionary; what we describe here is the language hackers use among themselves for fun, social communication, and technical debate. The download page, if you are interested.
  18. How I Learned to Program - I know I've posted quiet a few in the same vein, but this one is a little different than the rest. And I like the authors style.
  19. Before Python - Written by Guido van Rossum, the creator & Benevolent Dictator For Life, of Python about his programming experiences before Python. Also has a link to his other blog, - The History of Python.
  20. Advice from an Old Programmer - Zed Shaw, author of Learn Python the Hard Way gives some excellent advice, and then ends with - You can code. They cannot. That is pretty damn cool. (via @dedos from his post)
  21. Should Competent Programmers be "Mathematically Inclined?" - Jeff Atwood hits it out of the park again! If you aren't good at math, then that doesn't automatically mean you can't become a good programmer.
  22. "How much math do I need to know to program?" Not That Much, Actually - by, Al Sweigart, author of Invent Your Own Computer Games with Python.
  23. Code like a Pythonista - by David Goodger. Python style and Python idioms.
  24. Stop Using Print for Debugging - Al Sweigart, author of Invent Your Own Computer Games With Python, posts a 5 minute quickstart guide to the Python logging module. Debug the right way!
  25. on lisp - Official reddit blog on lisp and why they chose Python.
  26. Turning your code inside out - Every person who's regular on this forum - both the people who usually answered & the ones who usually asked questions, will find this post relevant, specially when it came to a special case of problems that a lot of people had.
  27. Write Code Like You Just Learned How To Code - Humm, this suggest that the people who started coding only during this course or weren't much familiar with coding before this course might have a better chance at winning the contest than the ones who have a much more extensive prior coding experience.
  28. A primer on Python decorators - Python functions as arguments, functions inside functions, functions that modify other functions, recursion, and memoization. It's easier than it sounds.
  29. Lucky to be a Programmer - Why programming is so awesome!
  30. How I created and launched a website from the internet cafe in Zimbabwe, Africa - Guy who has to code at night because of the electricity situation during the day, and without an internet connection makes a website and improves his career prospects

Happy reading!

THE DON'T JUST READ IT, MEMORIZE IT LIST

  1. xkcd - This is the most important resource in this list, so important that it's a list of it's own. You need to be proficient in your knowledge of xkcd, so proficient that you should be able to link situations you come across life(either Real of Online/Game) to specific xkcd strips wherever possible.

EDIT

This is now a community wiki. So anyone can add any good posts they've read.

There are just a few rules

  1. Think before you link. Not just about the quality, but also the topic & the content - is it relevant.
  2. Don't muck up the order of the posts. Don't try & arrange them in some kind of order. Just post the next link at the bottom of the list.
  3. And this is the most important one - DO NOT, UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE, TOUCH THE THE DON'T JUST READ IT, MEMORIZE IT LIST.

Alright then, drink link responsibly!

I'd tell you to drink responsibly, but

title: How to crawl a web page?
body: Wonder how we can use a web crawler to crawl the webpages?

While I'm enjoying learning Python, my gut reaction was to code this in C# initially. Here was the result:

var answer = Enumerable.Range(0, int.MaxValue).First(
    startingN =>
        {
            var n = startingN;
            return Enumerable.Range(0, 6).All(
                i =>
                    {
                        n--;
                        if (n <= 0 || n%5 != 0)
                            return false;
                        n -= n/5;
                        return true;
                    }
                );
        });

Console.Out.WriteLine("Answer found! There were {0} coconuts initially.", answer);

You're filtering out noise. All the frameworks surrounding Kalman Filter and friends include noise, that is, they are stochastic dynamic systems. The filters provide you with the "best", or "optimized" (usually in a minimum variance sense) estimate of your state variables (position, velocity, or whatever are your observation variables.)

For correct calculations, the values (at least sig) do need to be float. For the quiz, I handled that in my own code [leaving the initial integer values alone, by using float(mu) and float(sig). That is really only needed one time, since the first call to the update function will return float values [assuming any float arguments are used, and the measurements and measurement_sig ARE float], which should be used from then on.

Specifically, the calculation for new_var in the update function will be wrong, if either the passed in var1 or var2 is an integer.

title: So when are we actually going to be told why questions are incorrect?
body:
I'm a bit aggravated and a bit miffed. I spent almost two whole days working on the "Multiword Queries" question (7.3 Star), making sure it took everything into account, worked correctly in every possible test case (the huge list of them on the forums included), it passed everything, worked perfectly.

Checked the grade... Incorrect.
Why was it marked incorrect? Everything works exactly as intended.

Will you at least tell us what test cases your grading bots failed our questions on? The same thing happened with "Same Structure", yet it also passed every test case.

You asked for the code, here it is:

def multi_lookup(index, query):
    results = [] #hold our search results
    prev = {} #hold our previous loop's list pass results
    if len(query) == 1: #check if there's only one word
        return lookup(index, query[0]) #if there is, hand it off to baby lookup function
    for i in range(0, len(query)): #loop through each word in the query string
        if query[i] not in index: #check if the keyword is in the index
            return [] #if it's not, return nothing
        for list in index[query[i]]: #for each list in the index for the current query word
            if query[i] != query[0]: #if we're not the first word in the query string
                if query[i-1] not in prev[list[0][0]]: #check if the previous word failed this list
                    continue #if it did, restart and increment the loop
                if query[i-1] == list[1][0]: #check if previous word in the query string matches the keyword's 'previous' word for this url
                    if query[i] == query[-1]: # if we're the last word in the query string
                        if list[0][0] not in results: #and if the url isn't already in our results list
                            results.append(list[0][0]) #add url to results
                        continue #go to next loop
            if query[i] != query[-1]: #if we're not the last word in the query string
                if query[i] != query[0]: #and we're not the first word
                    if query[i-1] not in prev[list[0][0]]: #check if the previous word failed this list
                        continue #if it failed, restart and increment the loop
                if query[i+1] == list[1][1]: #check if next word in the query string matches the keyword's 'next' word for this url
                    if list[0][0] not in prev: #if we passed, check if a key for this url already exists in the pass dictionary
                        prev[list[0][0]] = [query[i]] #if it doesn't, make a new key and add us as the value
                    else: #if the key for this url DOES exist in the prev dictionary
                        prev[list[0][0]].append(query[i]) #Add on to that list instead
                    continue #go to next loop
                else: # if the next word in the query string does NOT match the keyword's 'next' word for this url
                    if list[0][0] not in prev: # and the key doesn't already exist
                        prev[list[0][0]] = [] #add a blank key for it
                    continue #go to next loop
    return results #GIVE ME THE FRUITS OF YOUR LABOR

def crawl_web(seed): # returns index, graph of inlinks
    tocrawl = [seed]
    crawled = []
    graph = {}  # <url>, [list of pages it links to]
    index = {} 
    while tocrawl: 
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            content = get_page(page)
            add_page_to_index(index, page, content)
            outlinks = get_all_links(content)
            graph[page] = outlinks
            union(tocrawl, outlinks)
            crawled.append(page)
    return index, graph

def get_next_target(page):
    start_link = page.find('<a href=')
    if start_link == -1: 
        return None, 0
    start_quote = page.find('"', start_link)
    end_quote = page.find('"', start_quote + 1)
    url = page[start_quote + 1:end_quote]
    return url, end_quote

def get_all_links(page):
    links = []
    while True:
        url, endpos = get_next_target(page)
        if url:
            links.append(url)
            page = page[endpos:]
        else:
            break
    return links

def union(a, b):
    for e in b:
        if e not in a:
            a.append(e)

def add_page_to_index(index, url, content):
    words = content.split()
    for i in range(0, len(words)):
        adjacent = [None, None]
        if i > 0:
            adjacent[0] = words[i-1]
        if i < len(words)-1:
            adjacent[1] = words[i+1]
        add_to_index(index, words[i], url, adjacent)

def add_to_index(index, keyword, url, adjacent):
    if keyword in index:
        index[keyword].append([[url], adjacent])
    else:
        index[keyword] = [[[url], adjacent]]

def lookup(index, keyword):
    kw = []
    if keyword in index:
        for e in index[keyword]:
            if e[0][0] not in kw:
                kw.append(e[0][0])
    return kw

cache = {
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/multi.html': """<html>
<body>

<a href="http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html">A</a><br>
<a href="http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html">B</a><br>

</body>
""", 
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html': """<html>
<body>

Monty likes the Python programming language
Thomas Jefferson founded the University of Virginia
When Mandela was in London, he visited Nelson's Column.

</body>
</html>
""", 
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html': """<html>
<body>

Monty Python is not about a programming language
Udacity was not founded by Thomas Jefferson
Nelson Mandela said "Education is the most powerful weapon which you can
use to change the world."
</body>
</html>
""", 
}

def get_page(url):
    if url in cache:
        return cache[url]
    else:
        print "Page not in cache: " + url
        return None

#Here are a few examples from the test site:

index, graph = crawl_web('http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/multi.html')

If all we had were the $%m_1 + m_2$%, you are right. But that's not all we have. We also have the term in the numerator, which is a difference. The numerator term basically says "when one mass is much bigger than the other, acceleration will be large," the bottom term says, "but don't forget that when you increase total mass, acceleration will go down."
This is one of those cases where there isn't an easy, elegant solution. You really have to break the problem into multiple parts and then grind through the algebra.

Good point Tim. The truth is, even if we were to use 9.81, we still wouldn't be getting the "right" answers for several reasons.

  1. 9.81 is still an approximation, not the exact value of acceleration anywhere on earth.
  2. That value varies by a small amount from place to place.
  3. Even if we WERE using the exact acceleration, our models of motion have been quite simple so far. We haven't been taking friction or air resistance into account (and these things are always present).

What I hope students get out of the class is a new way to approach and solve problems. Ten years from now, you may forget what the acceleration due to gravity is. No big deal, just look it up! What I hope you don't forget is the problem solving and data analysis tools that I hope you have learned: doing thought experiments to gauge the validity of a model, testing ideas with limiting cases, understanding uncertainty in measurement, etc...

This is a tricky one. The balloon is gaining potential energy, true. But it's displacing air, which is more dense than the helium in the balloon. That more dense air actually moves downwards, closer to the surface of the earth. That corresponds to a loss of potential energy.

This is a classic example of when it is difficult to know how big your system has to be. We are tempted to say the balloon alone is an isolated system, but it isn't. Great question!

Great point. You are absolutely right. When I solved this problem, I was using the assumption that the sun is "really far away."

Specifically, we could say that the distance to the sun (d), is much much bigger than the radius of the earth (r). When d >> r, motions along the surface of a disk shaped earth will only have negligible effect on the position of the sun.

For a spherical earth, even when the sun is very far away, motion along the sphere corresponds to noticeable change in the sun's position in the sky.

Great great question. The truth is... we don't go directly from proportionality to an equation. Knowing that $%a$% is proportional to $%F$% and inversely proportional to $%m$% tells us that the following equation is true: $$F=cma$$ Where c is some constant. Maybe that constant is 1, maybe it's 2 or 3 or 0.5. It turns out that this equation is SO important, that we actually choose to define our units in such a way that the constant is just 1 and $$F=ma$$

DJOldskool's answer will work, but could be tricky.

Instead of thinking of force, I would look at the elastic potential energy stored in the spring when it is compressed. That all gets converted to kinetic energy as the spring un-stretches. This will give you the velocity of the mass when it leaves the spring.

Once you have this velocity, you can use what we learned in unit 2 to calculate the distance it travels. This means that you will first have to calculate the time the object spends in the air (remember, $%v_{0y}$% will be zero), and then you can multiply this time by the $%v_{0x}$% that you found from conservation of energy to get the distance the object moves.

title: Gold Stars
tagnames: cs101 chrome search star homework gold
body:
This may seem like a stupid question, but what are the gold stars that the instructor was referring to in the homework? (Find 2 has 1 Gold Star)

I'm sure this has been answered, but the search isn't working.
HS student taking a class in Java and thought python would be interesting

I guess it's a question of evidence. They'll want black boxes (like those on planes) in these cars so they can analyse what happened: Was it foul play? Was is algorithmic error? Was it hardware failure? Evidence determines fault.

To gain wide acceptance, these cars not only need an emergency stop button, but must be very good at determining when they're about to kill their occupant(s) or hit pedestrians, other cars or other objects, and push the emergency stop button themselves, and then put a message up on the dashboard saying "I don't feel so good. Please call a mechanic."

My guess would be that you would experimentally derive it. Doing so requires taking many measurements in known settings (externally given orientation and acceleration) and determining the uncertainty from that data. I suspect some engineer somewhere has done this already for whatever sensor you are using, but getting access to that data may be impossible.

So far we have only really delved into the probability aspect. I'm not sure exactly where you are having trouble, but I highly recommend the Khan Academy. This link starts with the very basics, but feel free to skip videos until you get to something that is confusing to you.
