title: Unit 2 Video!
body: The Unit Video - 26 is getting stuck in many places!

It would be best to have all of these ideas rolled into a single community wiki, so here we go:

Website/Videos

  • Pop-up Python interpreter to follow along with the code in the videos.
  • When watching a video, if you click the "Class List" link at the top of the page, the list is brought up behind the video.
  • Showing the length of each video would be helpful in that it would allow students to allocate their time more appropriately and know how many videos they have time to watch. Also, showing the total video time for a given unit would be nice.
  • Having the introduction video start each time I load the "course content" page is very annoying. This should be changed so that the first video brought up is the next one I need to watch (or the previous one I watched, if I didn't finish it) and even then the video shouldn't start automatically.
  • Show the number of students registered for each course.
  • Localized times visible so people in different coutnries know when new lectures will be posted and when assignments/tests are due in their time zone.
  • Better instructions on how to access and complete quizzes. Quite possibly a full step-by-step tutorial would make the process easier.
  • An optional auto-play feature that will go from one video to another without user interaction.
  • Reference numbers for each video so that they may be easily tagged in questions on the forums.
  • Expected hours of work required for any given unit.
  • Summary video/section for each unit.
  • It would be nice to have an email sent out to all students when there is an important update to the site, such as a new homework assignment being posted.
  • When doing quizzes you are immediately given the answers if you get the question wrong even one time. This should be changed with an option to view the answers.
  • A more visible link to the forums is desirable; perhaps next to the 'Progress' link?
  • The importance of case (upper/lower) and white space in Python is not discussed.
  • Progress bars and game-like mechanics (see KhanAcademy) would be cool.
  • 'To learn more'-type link at the end of a video for those bold enough to want more.
  • Mobile support, make the site more accessible for mobile devices.
  • A calendar for each course would be really cool. Populate it with the dates of homework assignments, new videos, tests, etc.
  • Because the videos are hosted on YouTube, they are unavailable from more than a few countries. How about a mirror site where the videos can be downloaded?
  • The emails sent regarding updates in questions contain bad links.
  • PDF version of homework assignment similar to that of the course notes.
  • Khan Academy style quizzes/homeworks. This stems from the idea that mastery is better determined by continuing to do problems until you get enough right, as opposed to simply getting a homework questions right or wrong.
  • Different video speeds are a great idea. Not everything will be new to all students and some students may need to go slower than others. The ability to play the video at 0.75x, 1.00x, and 1.50x speed would be very useful.
  • A list of software that would be beneficial to students taking the course (such as where to download Python 2.7 and which IDE to use) would be tremendously helpful to new students with little programming background.
  • Until the answer videos are actually available, the 'Next' button should take students to the next question.
  • Links to additional exercises would be good for students who want to go above and beyond.
  • A single account for the main website and all forums would be ideal.
  • Fractional answers to quizzes/homework should be accepted.
  • In addition to auto-play, an auto buffer next video, if current has finished buffering option, if possible would be nice. With my slow internet, I'd have to open the next video in a new tab for it to start buffering after the current one has finished.
  • Add some (more)text in the instructor comments. The summary of the video from the units lecture notes would be just fine. Would give people with a slow internet with something to do while the video buffers. Though if you take a look at the Tangle javascript library, it would be nice if you could incorporate that into the instructor comments. Would make for nice, interactive notes that would add to the experience of learning.
  • Make it possible after due date to view the answer one submitted to the homework (to see if one forgot to click submit, or to see if maybe some modifications were made after due date which make it impossible to see why the homework was graded incorrect in retrospect)
  • Re-do the video lecture on TraceRoute (4.17) as there were many mistakes (192.168.1.1 being described as local host, not realizing that traceroute shows roundtrip delay, etc.) Re-do the homework question (4.4) that asks about latency to Cambridge from Palo Alto. Routers don't cause as much latency as the question assumes. The question and "right" answer are invalid because they are based on the misunderstanding about traceroute and roundtrip time.

Forums

  • More intuitive formatting. Making this list caused me a great deal of annoyance.
  • Provide an option to show which courses a user is currently registered in/has previously completed.
  • The ability to message other users on the forum is definitely needed.
  • Optional subscribing to threads as opposed to the current auto-subscribing.
  • Actually limit daily voting. I currently have -2 votes left for today and can still vote on posts.
  • Make the FAQ button larger and more noticeable. Perhaps stick it on the bar with the links 'Questions', 'Tags', 'Users', etc.
  • Attempting to sort questions by 'hottest' gives a 504 error.
  • Community wiki's aren't editable by another other than the creator, despite karma. A short explanation should be given. - [This appears to be false]
  • More than one answer can be accepted for any thread.
  • Karma is not rewarded when your comment gets voted up.
  • Suggest the use of standardized tags for commenting on homeworks/quizzes such as HW1.9, to help avoiding the multiplication of same questions on the same topic.
  • Consolidate forums with other courses?
  • Enable sticky posts for currently frequently asked questions, so the forums aren't spammed with 100 variations of the same problem.
  • There should be options to flag a question as 'Non-constructive' and 'Possible duplicate', in addition to the already available options.
  • A separate forum should exist for threads of general, non-course related discussions. This will have the added bonus of not clogging up the course forums with irrelevant material.
  • Having the formatting details shown when writing comments would be helpful.
  • Rather than requiring a separate account for each forum, link forum access to course enrollment and maintain posting statistics across courses.

Recommended additions to the FAQ

  • Why was Python chosen as the language for CS101?
  • The Canonical List of Known Bugs and Issues
  • Etiquette/Netiquette on the forum
  • Formatting your Python code

NOTE: If a Udacity employee wanted to contact me in some way to let me know which of these changes have been made, then I would be glad to remove them from the list.-

title: homework 2
body: when the answers for HM-2 will be out???

Kilograms are a unit of mass. Your mass doesn't change when you, for example, go to the moon.

Newtons and pounds are both units of force. Weight is a force. When you measure your weight, you are measuring the FORCE a scale needs to supply to hold you up. When you go to the moon, your weight decreases.

Write a program to print out the two positive prime numbers that add up to a number. This is the Goldbach conjecture, for even integers. The Goldbach conjecture states that every even integer is the sum of two prime numbers; although no one has ever proven it right or wrong.

'''
Created on Mar 26, 2012
@author: Algoribinna

'''

Generate primes to N using sieve of erastosthenes

def primesToN(n):

#Generates all prime numbers below n using the sieve of erastosthenes
#A boolean value of True represents a prime while False represents a composite

    c = 0  
    p = []

    while c<n:
        #Initialize all values to True
        p.append(True)
        c = c+1

    #set 0 and 1 to False, since they are not primes    
    p[0] = False
    p[1] = False

    i=2    
    while i*i<=n:
        # start from i= 2 to sqrt(n) i.e i*i <=n 
        j = i+i
        while j<n:
            #cross out all multiples of i from j=2*i to n
            if p[j] == True:
                p[j]=False
            j = j + i #increment j by i since you want to cross out multiples of i    
        i = i + 1    
    return p;

Now the actual algorithm for Goldbach conjecture!

def sumOfTwoPrimes(n):

    #Checks if a number is the sum of two primes
    #It uses the primesToN() function to generate all primes up to n (i.e below n+1)

    p = primesToN(n+1)
    i=0
    while i<=n-i:
        #Since i + n-i add up to n, if both i and n-i are primes, then n is the sum of two prmes 
        if p[i]==True and p[n-i]==True:
            print (i,n-i) #display i and n-i
        i = i+1

sumOfTwoPrimes(1000) # 1000 is just a test value!

I don't think it matters, there was no comment about it in the explanation so I'm assuming that it doesn't matter.

This is a pretty unintuitive thing. We don't think of the ground as capable of pushing but it really can. Try it right now. Push your hand on the ground. The harder you push, the more force you feel. You are not feeling the force of you pushing on the ground. What you're feeling is the ground pushing up on you.

Not only that, but the force with which you are pushing on the ground is identical to the force with which it is pushing on you.

Your list only has one item in it. You can add items in a few ways:

  1. Manually: [1./n,1./n,1./n,1./n,1./n]. This is brittle because it can only work for 1 n
  2. List comprehensions: [1./n for i in range(n)]. This is a fast a Pythonic way to express a loop.
  3. A regular for loop: for i in range(n):p.append(1./n). This is the most basic and universal across languages.
  4. The list multiplication operator: [1./n]*n. This is the most concise and works by adding (concatenating) the list to itself n-1 times.

I was thinking that we shouldn't include the HW4.6 modification because of the order in which the homework problems were presented. If you wanted to include both of the modifications, it would make sense to implement click counts first, then modify that code to save only unique urls. Then each problem need be solved only once. In the order presented, the click counts have to be implemented one way in HW4.6 and then a different, more complex, way in HW4.7. Doesn't make sense from a pedantic standpoint, and if it really were intended the instructions should have pointed out the need for modifying both routines. It seems (or seemed) more likely that only the uniqueness modification is desired.

But Tomas's comment is correct: the HW4.7 answer can't be right in a real-world application if counts could be assigned arbitrarily to any of several urls. Either the url should be made unique, as in HW4.6, or we are relying on the code to always increment the first instance and ignore all counts for duplicate keyword-url pairs. The latter approach has possible uses, but we would use a different data structure instead of storing all those unreachable counts. Clearly the instructor is heading toward the first option of having only unique urls for each keyword.

Both lines of reasoning seem valid, but useful function trumps pedantic elegance. I'll go with including both modifications unless we get guidance otherwise.

title: Homework: Lessons Learned
body:
There are quite a lot of homework questions (which is understandable, expected and there is nothing wrong about it). The thing about it is that majority of them falls into only few categories of repeating the same type of mostly silly mistakes. Thus, it looks as a good idea to collect them somewhere in order for everyone to be able to learn from that resource and do not make the same mistake again.

I will start with the ones I remember just from the top of my head and feel free to edit this post and add yours "lessons learned" (I am marking this post as community wiki in order for everyone to be able to directly edit it.):

  • Read the assignment very carefully and do exactly what you were asked for:

If it says "print number of seconds", do not print string "Number of seconds is: %d". Print only that number, you were asked for. Also make sure you looked at the comments under the video and that you really understand what you are supposed to do (e.g. this was my problem for the first question, where I did not notice the HTML below the video and simply marked all URL's, which had valid format).

  • Distinguish between "print" and "output":

While it is little confusing also for me, because when someone says "output", I understand "print", by default, this term was very clearly defined in Unit2.3 and following videos. Thus, distinguish between these:

  • "print": Print out something to standard output (do not confuse standard output a.k.a. stdout with return), i.e. use call to print.
  • "output": Return something out from the function, i.e. use call to return.
  • Test, test, test!:

Make sure you actually test your solution before submitting it. Try to cover especially border cases. Also make sure you test on correct environment, e.g. there are multiple versions of Python and they are not 100% compatible, thus even if you did extensive testing on your local Python installation, run it at least once (try to cover all lines of code) in the embedded online interpreter directly on this site in order to be sure that there are no compatibility issues.

  • Make sure your output does not contain any extras, such as debug messages and the like:

As Aleksey P stated in one of the threads, such code is not suitable neither for production nor for homework submission.

  • Make sure you DO NOT REPEAT anything from above the comment:

This one seems pretty obvious, but it includes also cases, where many homeworks failed, because some variable defined above that comment was overwritten by some hardcoded value below it. In other words, don't copy what is above the comment to below it. If you do this, the grading software can not change the variable and test your code properly.

  • Do not hardcode "magic values":

If the question says that you have to find second occurrence of the target string and gives an example of search string "De l'audace, encore de l'audace, toujours de l'audace" and target string "audace", make sure that your code does not look just for the string "audace". You need to use input argument as a target string, instead.

  • Do not remove comments already there:

Removing comments can mean you remove the place the autograder is using to determine where your code starts so it can't check it.

  • Do not use Python's built-in identifiers for your own identifiers:

Albeit it will sometimes work (at least somehow) it definitely is not considered a good practice to "recycle" programming language's own built-in names (such as Python's str, int, round, max, etc.), because such "recycled" identifiers may clash with the original identifiers and produce unexpected or even undefined behavior.

  • Do not submit "multiple answers":

If the assignment is wants you e.g. to implement a function XYZ and you know more than one solution, choose and submit exactly one of them. I.e. do not submit source code, containing multiple XYZ functions, each of them containing one of your correct solutions.

  • Measure twice and cut once:

Before submitting, reread the assignment again, check and recheck all the small details, such as name of the function you created, for the devil is in the details. Better to spend few more seconds on rechecking your work than be sorry after homework was graded.

  • Check your homework few hours before deadline:

It may happen, that some new hints will have appeared after your submission. It might be a good idea to check it and eventually rethink your answer if that is the case. Make sure that you do not resubmit wrong answer, though (e.g. in case you ran the code you do not want to be submitted as answer, recheck that it was not saved by some accident, etc. - see "measure twice and cut once" hint above).

This class rocks! Took physics in high school, back then it seemed boring and overly complex. The methods used to teach in this class really clarify things. These methods really seem to fortify the link between material and what I observe in everyday life. Please, keep on rocking my world.

Fun question:Infinite Errors basically had it, but missed the round trip (nice picture for boat B by the way). To account for the return voyage $%t_A$% should also have a term that looks like $%t_A = \frac{d}{v-u}$% (notice that time gets huge as v approaches u, since then the boat can't make the return journey), and $%t_b$% should be doubled. Carrying out the algebra I get $$\frac{t_A}{t_B} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-r^2}}$$

where $%r= \frac{u}{v}$%

Nice question!

title: hw2.5 doubt
body:
The question 5 is a little ambiguous, right?

I made many tests with a python compiler and a lot of numbers, and the code always finishes.

#
# Question: How many routes are there through a 20x20 grid? (combinations problem)
# Answer = (40)!/(20!*20!)
# We can move only down and right, in this case there are the same numbers of down and right movements.
# We have 20 down movements and 20 rigt movements giving us a total of 40 movements for each possible route.
# Now if we choose all the "right" movements we already have also the down movements (or vise versa)
# then whe need to find the number of ways we have for choosing 20 movements from a total of 40.
# that is: (40)!/ (20!*((40)-20)!)
# The general formula: (rows+columns)!/(rows!*columns!)

def factorial(n):
    nf=1
    for i in range(1, n+1):
        nf=nf*i
    return nf

rows=20
columns=20

print "For a ", rows, "x", columns," grid whe have ", factorial(rows+columns)/(factorial(rows)*factorial(columns)), " routes"

My version..Not that much variations. Like Anne I'm not a fan of globals
but since they were there I used them ;)

# set up probablities matrix
m = len(colors)     # rows in world
n = len(colors[0])  # cols in world
normDistr = 1.0 / (m*n)
p = [ [normDistr for i in range(n)] for j in range(m)]

def sense(p,Z):
    # calculate nonnormalized posterior
    q = [ [p[i][j] * (sensor_right if colors[i][j]==Z  else 1.0-sensor_right)
            for j in range(n)]
            for i in range(m)]
    s = sum( [ sum(v) for v in q]) # sum for all values in q
    # return normalized matrix
    return map( lambda x: map ( lambda y: y/s, x), q)

def move(p, U):
    # make resulting matrix for succeesful moves
    q = [ [p_move * p[(i-U[0])%m][(j-U[1])%n] for j in range(n)] for i in range(m) ]
    # add probablities for unsuccesful moves
    for i in range(m):
        for j in range(n):
            q[i][j] += p[i][j] * (1.0 - p_move)
    return q

# do the move/sense cycles
for i in range(len(motions)):
    p = move(p, motions[i])
    p = sense(p, measurements[i] )

--EDIT--

Since I couldn't find another way to post the equations here, I put the literal latex code which can be pasted into http://www.codecogs.com/latex/eqneditor.php

When multiplying the two gaussians, we get some constants term multiplied with some exponential term again. We can ignore the constant term, because that one has to be replaced with a new normalization factor anyway in order to make the result gaussian. The exponential multiply like this:

e^{- {1 \over 2} {(x - \mu)^2 \over \sigma^2} } \cdot e^{- {1 \over 2} {(x - \nu)^2 \over \tau^2} } = e^{- {1 \over 2} \left( {(x - \mu)^2 \over \sigma^2} +  {(x - \nu)^2 \over \tau^2} \right ) }

Now, since the value of the exponent will always be negative, this function will reach its peak when the value in the parentheses is minimal. To calculate this minimum, we need to find the value x for which the first derivative is zero:

{d \over dx} \left( {(x - \mu)^2 \over \sigma^2} + {(x - \nu)^2 \over \tau^2} \right ) = 2 \left ( {{x-\mu} \over \sigma^2} + {{x - \nu} \over \tau^2}\right ) = 0

When you solve this for x, you get:

x = {{\nu\sigma^2 + \mu\tau^2} \over {\sigma^2 + \tau^2}}

This is obviously our new mean, because this is the position of the highest peak in the resulting function.

Now for calculating the variance, we use the fact, that the second derivative of the same term in the exponent of the gaussian function will be 2/sigma_2, which means it's not dependent on x or the mean anymore. So for our new gaussian with mu' and sigma', we should get the following equation:

{{d^2}\over {dx^2}} {\left( {(x - \mu)^2 \over \sigma^2} + {(x - \nu)^2 \over \tau^2} \right )} = {{2\over \sigma^2} + {2 \over \tau^2 }} = {2 \over \sigma'^{2}} = {{d^2}\over {dx^2}} {\left( {(x - \mu')^2 \over \sigma'^2}\right )}

You can now solve this for sigma' and get the new variance:

\sigma'^2 = {1 \over {{1\over\sigma^2}+{1\over\tau^2} }}

title: hw3.3 what about the empty list?
body:
I've got a function that works for any list with a number in it. But what should our function return if the list is empty?

I could also have the function return zero or -1. But they're not great choices since they could be the result of a valid list multiplication. I could print a warning, but that might invalidate my answer if the algorithm wasn't expecting it.

If I don't add a check for the empty list, then the function will just return 1. Is this ok?

Thanks!

I think that graph theory provides an elegant solution.

Let A be the adjacency matrix for a 20x20 square lattice. (A^n)_{i,j} will count the number of paths from vertex i to vertex j. The maximum possible path length can be bounded above by the number of edges.

If the upper left vertex corresponds to vertex 1 and the lower right corresponds to vertex 400, then I believe the answer would be

\sum_{n = 1}^{# edges} (A^n)_{1,400}

But perhaps this is not algorithmically nice.
Here's a followup that discusses similar concerns.

More less, you're not going to get much out of it if you simply look at the answers without trying the problems.

My recommendation is as followed:

Spend time to try to get the answer yourself. Especially true with the programming problems. Try 3-4 times. However, there is no point in banging your head again the wall. start the answer video. Stop it as soon as you come across something that should improve what your doing. The idea then is to create working code before finishing the answer video. However, if that doesn't work, then finish the video, code the answer, submit and get it correct, and you'll at least see what good code looks like.

The benefit here is that you can learn at your own pace. Even at an accelerated pace. Looking like I'll have this course done in under 3 weeks). Which is good as I needed to get familiarized with myself with Python before I tackled the more interesting courses on here.

tagnames: cs101 multiplication interpreter nested run browser
body:
Do the majority of people work at solving this stuff with a scratchpad (paper, or electronic) at hand, or is it just enter the code, cut/copy when necessary to clipboard? (and hope you don't copy something else by reflex). I have been doing this mainly reclining in bed (it's officially 6a.m. now) and lazy to get pad and pencil. I suspect there are better ways to abuse my body. Am beginning to get comfortable working directly on the screen like my sons do but ensconced in bed, I keep putting off the intricate bits which may require the 'rough book' as we called the scratchpad in my childhood.

title: homework 3.3
body:
Hi All,
about hw 3.3
when the list is empty , the output is 0 or 1?

I''m going out on a limb here, both because I know so little about you and because I am recommending a path that I have not followed.

You are getting advice to improve your coding skills via classes. Great, if you can afford the time and cost, but those classes will simply put you in competition with all of the other graduates. If what you need is a programming job, consider community college classes. These are often sponsored by local industry and have ties to the local job market. My wife once took a TAL class for instance -- the language for programming Tandem computers. Not a big market for that, but there were jobs at Tandem for some of the graduates. Community college graduates are also good candidates for sysop jobs and other infrastructure positions. From there you can work your way into other programming positions, if you so choose.

Alternatively, contact local corporations directly and ask about their training programs. Here's one in today's news: Facebook has just agreed to pay the city of Menlo Park $15M over 15 years for the right to exceed 3,600 on-site employees. As part of the deal, Facebook has agreed to create a summer internship program for local high school students and to develop a local career training and outreach program; they will also be investing in affordable local housing.

If you can't get into a local training program, perhaps you can be hired for help desk work or some other peripheral task. Then you can network inside the company and you get first crack at the internal job postings.

Another low-level entry route is to help people or small businesses with their personal computer problems, freelance or with a business service. You need some skills to get hired for this, of course, but relatively few up-front skills if you freelance -- and it can be done part time. Retired people sometimes get into computing by volunteering their services to local charities or school clubs, though of course that doesn't generate income. Anyway, the point is to get started with what you know and then gradually add to your skills, rather than feel that you have to learn a dozen languages and systems up front. The basic principle of getting hired is to find someone who has a problem and some budget authority, but who can't or doesn't want to do the work him/herself. Managers with problems and time constraints are easy to find, and budget is often available as well. You just have to be willing to start with the work that no one else wants to do, at unattractive pay, on obsolete systems, in a language no one cares about -- or some subset of the above. And you have to sell yourself, on your initiative, personality, and potential if not on your skills. (Skills can be trained, or self-trained.)

In general, I would recommend getting experience over getting a degree. But talk to some Personnel directors; see what they say. And ask managers to explain the kind of coding/programming/IT experience they are looking for. Check with you nearest ACM or IEEE chapters (or equivalent) as well; the officers and members will probably be happy to advise you, even if you are not a member.

Wow. Deep question Manish. I don't have a satisfying answer, though I can at least recommend this for further reading and if that interests you I would focus on the thermodynamic aspect as presented here.

There is a quantity, called entropy, that has some respect for time. It only ever increases with time! Nothing else behaves like that. Other physical quantities are either constant (like energy) or can vary without any real respect for time (like a particle's velocity).

Once you've read a bit about entropy and the arrow of time, you should take a look at Isaac Asimov's short story The Last Question.

# A list is symmetric if the first row is the same as the first column,
# the second row is the same as the second column and so on. Write a
# procedure, symmetric, which takes a list as input, and returns the
# boolean True if the list is symmetric and False if it is not.
def symmetric(p):
    x = 0
    y = 0
    n = len(p[0])
    while x < n:
        while x < n:
            if p[x][y] <> p[y][x]:
                return False
            x = x + 1
        y = y + 1    
    return True

title: HW2.5 Collatz Conjecture prove attempt
tagnames: cs101 loops hw2.5 collatz conjecture prove
body:
The homework 2.5 became very interesting due to its nature... here comes my few pennies to the homework dealing with the Collatz conjecture..

Well, so, we have still few weeks to prove that the serie converges to 1 in order to get the full credits :-)

There are no proves yet, so let's "propose" this ;-) ....

OK, so what do we know about the serie? First of all, the serie converges to 1, if the iterated value (or plain) n becomes or is of the power of two (as 1,2,4,etc => ...,4,2,1).

Therefore for some point of time, regardless how long we calculated, iterated and how many rounds of n we have made in our function, the following statement must be true in order to converge to 1:

3x + 1 = x^2

Therefore, if this is "not true or it cannot be true" => there must be a non-real (complex) number solution to this => there exists a value that makes our code loop forever.
In other words, the equation must have a solution producing only real numbers, thus having always a real solution.

Note that we are not interested by the x "or n" itself in the proving, but the equation only, that it has a solution in the world of real numbers - no imaginary parts/numbers whatsoever. In such an imaginary case, we expect only an eternal loop.
The idea is somewhat like proving that "the plane 3x+1 cuts the plane x^2".

From that point of view we need to show that there is always (real) value solution to our equation.

Let's modify the equation a bit

3x + 1 = x^2

=> x^2 - 3x - 1 = 0

=> 1*x^2 - 3x - 1 = 0

Remember from math lessons that:
ax^2 + bx + c = 0, where a is not 0

=> x = (-b [+-] sqrt(b^2 - 4ac))/2*a

The square root part (b^2 - 4ac) is called discriminant D.
So, these holds:

( 1 ) if D > 0, then the equation has two real value solutions x1, x2 (ok in our case, as we need to show that there exists a real value solution whatever n is)

( 2 ) if D = 0, then the equation has a doubled solution x1 = x2 (ok in our case as above)

( 3 ) if D < 0, then the equation does not have real number solutions => meaning that there are not any chances to solve our problem, i.e. there exists a value n that is not real (ie., complex)), "the planes do not cut", and that causes the eternal loop

So, for our purpose it is enough to show that the discriminant is equal or bigger than 0 to be sure that our loop stops.

To apply that info to our equation:

x = (-(-3) [+-] sqrt( (-3)^2 - 41(-1) ) ) / ( 2 * 1 )

=> x = ( 3 [+-] sqrt( 9 - (-4) ) ) / 2

=> x = ( 3 [+-] sqrt(9+4) ) / 2

=> x = ( 3 [+-] sqrt(13) ) / 2

=> x1 = ( 3 + sqrt(13) ) / 2
=> x2 = ( 3 - sqrt(13) ) / 2

Discriminant D = 13
=>
A) because D is positive, there always is a real number solution => the loop (n) converges always at some point of time to 1 via the squared serie. "The planes cuts each other"

B) because D is not negative (solution is not a complex number), does not loop forever, i.e., converges always to 1 meaning that while loop stops at some point of time with whatever n is.

There is always a real solution to our "3x + 1 = x^2" equation, meaning that the 3x+1 plane cuts the squared plane (x^2) at some point and the loop ends via the serie of (.., 4, 2, 1). The equality proves the cutting of the planes.

3 * (( 3 + sqrt(13) ) / 2) + 1 == (( 3 + sqrt(13) ) / 2) ^ 2)

10.908... == 10.908...

Proved.

... or...
Well, I'm not a mathematician but this sounds good... some mathematicians attending in cs101 could elaborate this idea ... Well, in any case I made an attempt to this open question :-)

In the real world the number one largest expense for any software project of any size is maintenance. The number one cause of unmaintainable code are developers that think they're being clever and seeing if they can leverage interesting and sometimes obscure portions of a programming language to minimize line count. PLEASE DO NOT GET SUCKED INTO THIS TRAP! Write clear maintainable code that not only you but somebody you've never met can understand and maintain.

Granted the problems covered in this course don't span thousands (or millions) of lines of code but start off on the right foot and start building habits that encourage quality code.

That being said I have no doubt that a Python guru could probably do the sudoku problem in one line with a list comprehension and a lambda ;) I don't consider myself a guru so I haven't tried so this is total conjecture on my part.

title: Website doesn't want to be crawled
body: What would be the possible reasons for a website not wanting to be crawled?

I don't think my solution is better or worse than the way you propose or any other one proposed so far, but I haven't seen yet a similar approach. I thought it was the logical or easy way of solving this max depth problem, but I was wrong, or at least my logic was not as logical as I thought ;).

I post this solution here because I think it could be interesting to see a different approach to solve the max_depth problem using recursion instead of the more spread way with the two loops + union.

def crawl_pages(tocrawl, crawled, max_depth):
    if max_depth < 0:
        return
    while tocrawl:
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            crawled.append(page)
            crawl_pages(get_all_links(get_page(page)), crawled, max_depth - 1)

def crawl_web(seed,max_depth):
    tocrawl = [seed]
    crawled = []
    crawl_pages(tocrawl, crawled, max_depth)
    return crawled

You can check HW3.7 alternative solutions - why is instructors better? for alternative solutions.

If you struggle to figure something out, keep trying. Come at it from different angles, research and read material you don't understand, just keep doggedly trying to inhale information and solving things step-by-step. Good programmers are hackers, in the old sense of the word. They just keep worrying a problem until they solve it...then worry it some more until they are happy with the solution.

Great programmers are also great debuggers, so learn to debug your program with print statements, extra variables, step debugging etc. Python is a pretty good environment for developing code; I find myself running the web editor, a simple Python terminal, and a full-fledged Python IDE all at once, and moving around between them fluidly as I work. The IDE is great for saving different versions of files and integrating parts, the console window is great for trying out a few simple lines of code to test operations, and sometimes it's easiest just to work in the web client.
Write Python ..... hours in 7 weeks Windows 7 Explorer

Not on an individual basis, no. There was something mentioned about looking into ways to regrade to take away some of the problems but whether they will have time to do that or not before the course ends, or even come up with a good solution, I don't know.

Hopefully you will do so well on the other homeworks that this one wont even count towards your grade. Even if the homeworks go badly, it's still possible to get 100% on the course if you get a perfect score on the exam since if your exam result is better than the homework results then just the exam counts.

title: Homework 3.1 Lists, what is being asked?
body: I am not clear about what is being asked in this question?

Wow, I didn't think I'd get this question. But I am happy to answer it!

First: yes, I took this course, but not in the same way that all of you probably have. Part of my job is to review the units after they are edited, which means I have to go through every video, make sure there are no obvious content or editing mistakes, and then start putting together the quizzes and programming exercises. The review phase has to happen quickly, which means I don't always get to attempt each programming exercise before I have to watch the solution video.

That being said, I tried to solve as many programming exercises and homework problems as I could squeeze in.

Was this course easy? No! But I love challenging courses, so I had a really fun time solving the problems that I did. There would also be occasions when I would be watching a solution video and be so excited by the elegance of a solution that I would pause, call over all the Udacity engineers, and show the solution to them. For example, the function which creates a scrabble board from only 1/4 of a board in unit 6 is something that I really appreciated. Physicists love symmetry, and I really liked that Peter was able to identify a symmetry in this problem and use it to his advantage. When I called the engineers over for this one the office basically stopped working for 30 minutes while we discussed it.

As far as my experience before this: I am very new to both Python and programming in general. Before Udacity, my programming experience was limited to some basic matlab scripts to analyze data and fit curves. In February I TA'ed CS 373 and took CS 101 and learned a lot through those courses and through discussions with Peter Chapman (one of the other TAs). So yes, I learned a TON of new tricks (some of which I posted on Andy's Corner and the Python Glossary, which I hope were helpful for the students who were new to programming). Generator expressions, decorators, and memoization are some of my favorite new 'tricks.'

I think the three biggest take aways from this course for me are the importance of selecting the right representation for a problem (as in, should I model this as a set? A list of lists? A string?); the necessity of planning when solving big problems; and the importance of modularity in code. The functions that I write now are much shorter, accomplish one specific task, and are therefore much more modular, useful, and easy to debug than they used to be.

Thanks for the question Brett.

Having worked closely with Professor Norvig for the past 7 weeks I can confirm that this is true. He has indeed gotten older (7 weeks to be exact). Alas, even super python skills are no match for the inexorable march of time.

In all seriousness, this class has been quite an experience. I know I've learned a lot, and I hope you all have too. And thanks for saying hi the other day Ken!
Thanks Christine, I've added a link. I will probably film an addition to the glossary on argument unpacking today.
Look at "Instructor Comments" area below the video.
15/F here, although I think I might be 16 by the time this course ends!

title: 'print' versus 'return':  To print or Not to print
tagnames: cs101 print return homework procedure quiz
body:
Several posts have commented on confusion in quiz/homeworks over whether to print, or return, or whatever. For example, unit3.24 sick of this return/print thing, you just can't win...

Rather than trying to answer all those posts individually, here's a guide. I hope it helps. Please, anyone, jump in with corrections, suggestions, exceptions, etc. This is marked community wiki.

Print, or Not?

There are 3 possible situations in this class, thus far:

  1. The quiz/homework wants you to write a procedure that "returns" or "outputs" or "produces" some specific result. That means your procedure, beginning with the 'def' statement, will have one or more 'return' statements somewhere (often at the end). You will write the desired result immediately following the 'return' word, as in, 'return p'. When that 'return' is executed, the result will "return" or "output" BACK to the program line that "called" (used) the procedure. There is NO printing involved. DO NOT use a 'print' anywhere! The auto-grader, which is itself a program, will call (use) your procedure, and check that it gives back the right result. This is probably the most common case.

  2. The quiz/homework wants you to write a program that prints some specific result -- the wording will say "print" explicitly. The context should be clear that it's the PROGRAM doing the printing, NOT a procedure. Thus, even if writing a procedure is involved, any 'print' statements go OUTSIDE your procedures. DO NOT put a 'print' anywhere inside a procedure in this case! Do the printing in the body of the program, not indented under a 'def'. The auto-grader will run your entire program, and look to see that the right result is printed out.

  3. The quiz/homework wants you to write a procedure that prints some specific result. The wording will explicitly say to write or make a procedure, and have it print something. In this case, you put the 'print' statements INSIDE the procedure, somewhere under the 'def'. There need not be any result returned if all the procedure must do is print something. However, it's possible for a procedure to do both: print something, and also return a result. Read carefully to clarify. The auto-grader will call your procedure, and check that it prints out the right result.

Other situations are possible, but these are what we've seen so far, as far as I can remember. If a more complicated case comes up, try to figure it out by breaking apart the problem into a combination of two or more of these three cases.

One other note: it's a good idea to use temporary 'print' statements liberally for testing. Put them any place in your programs and procedures that helps you figure out if what you wrote works correctly. But don't forget to remove them again before submitting!

Summary:

  1. If the problem is to "write a procedure" that "outputs" or "returns" or "produces," then NO 'print' should appear anywhere. Use a 'return' to complete the procedure.
  2. If the problem is to "write a program" that "prints" something, your 'print' statements go OUTSIDE any procedures.
  3. If the problem is to "write a procedure" that "prints" something, your 'print' statements go INSIDE the procedure.

Thanks for asking about Saylor.org! I'm the Community & External Affairs Manager for the Saylor Foundation, and wanted to fill you in on a couple of aspects about Saylor.org.

Regarding our business model: we are an operating 501(c)(3) Foundation. It is our mission to provide all of our educational courses and associated resources (like textbooks, our ePortfolio, and more) for free. We will never charge our students to take a course or for a certificate of completion.

And to Vincin's point about universities offering credits for these free educational resources, we are working to make that happen for students that are interested in formal credits. This year, we've announced partnerships with StraighterLine and Excelsior College that will allow students to take select courses at Saylor.org and then pay a small fee to either StraighterLine or Excelsior to take a credit-bearing exam built upon those particular courses. If you have any questions about our efforts to build college credit partnerships, you can send an email to Devon Ritter who's heading up our student/credit partnerships effort at devon.ritter@saylor.org.

Thanks, and best of luck with your studies!

Camie

title: H2.6: Ambiguity in question?
body: I wonder whether there is an ambiguity in the question. I think you could read the question as asking for the position of the end of the last occurrence of the target string. Could this be clarified, please? Thanks!

I am wary about using tools that inherently incorporate arbitrary parameters such as the width of the bars.

Are you wary of daily, monthly, and early statistics? How would you represent the data to see how the number of users who completed ST101 changes over time? Are they more active during summer or winter? Did the weekly email nag improve the completion rate? The majority of all business metrics visualisations are bar charts (or line charts incorrectly used instead of bar charts), because you want to know how metrics change over time.

But you're right that bar charts can introduce a bias due to the choice of bin boundaries. One such example was presented in "Picturing the Uncertain World" by H.Wainer. He examined the scores obtained on computer-administered exam as a function of the amount of delay caused by a computer malfunction. And solely due to the choice of bins the result was unexpected - the longer the delay caused by malfunction, the higher the score.

But you can easily avoid such anomalies by using error bars.

title: Homework2.5: Bonus Question
body:
I spent last hour or so reading various comments on homework question 2.5.3 and I am under impression, that some kind of union will eventually form and then declare a general strike of some sort. :) So I have a bonus question for HW2.5:

Why are you taking this course?

a) To get (arguably useless) sheet of paper with some numbers and signatures on it.

b) To learn something.

In case your answer was a), then please note that at least for now (I can't predict future though and actually I hope they will manage something like that), that sheet of paper is virtually useless, since Udacity has no accreditation (and as far as I know they are not searching to obtain any, but again, I can be mistaken). Moreover, if I was an employer (in fact I was for a time and I hardly looked at resumes and formal education of candidates - partially because of the poor state of universities in this part of the world and partially because of I prefer to trust what I see myself, not what others tell to me I should believe.), I would not give such a paper any credit, since it can not be proved that you earned it yourself and you were not helped by some friend or so - Internet is very strange place to be, in this respect.

I can second the motion:

  • that the partial scoring would be "more fair" (but how is "fair" defined and what actually is "fair", after all?),

  • that it is not the best practice to change assignments (hints and function definitions added) after they were aired and already solved by many,

  • that this question was tricky and should have been part of quiz, rather than homework, or at least homework in some later unit

However, when rising up such motions, one should notice also those four letters to the right of the "Udacity" logo at each page (saying "BETA"). In fact, Udacity had only one experience with such an endeavour - the Standford AI class. This one is only the second one. That is reason for that "BETA" thingie. They are still learning and working around the clock to deal with all day-to-day problems (such as heavy traffic peak due to an article in really popular medium). They are also only people such as me and you and they need to do a few mistakes before "BETA" can go away. Let's try to give them that opportunity - they need it and I think they deserve it and also that they will do their best to use it. Also, let's not forget that we are getting all of this for free!

Anyway, I can not help myself, but I think that this was the best question from HW2 - because, as I wrote in my other posts, it gives very little example of how programmers job in real life truly looks like. You are not inventing a wheel most of the time (unless you are a researcher, but that is not typical programmer's job). In case you want to be productive, you do not have that luxury - deadlines are tough, customer does not really know what he wants (it is your job to find out), functional specification is incomplete and sometimes it is also contradicting itself (business analyst is also only a man), code you are working on consists of few million (and more) lines of code and 90% of it looks like the one who wrote it was just in process of learning the language he used, testers are submitting bug tickets saying only "something is not working" without any closer specification nor debug trace, 3 from 5 of your key team members get really ill right before the deadline etc etc. Thus you do not have any time to play brain-teasing games. When you need to find a solution to your problem, you search the web (or other resources at hand). And it is usually much harder than HW2.5.3 assignment, because you need to overcome all of the above mentioned problems and still deliver quality code and deliver it on time. Otherwise your customer will not be satisfied and you are risking not getting your salary (even more, if you are a freelancer).

So, my message in short is: Do not complain about HW2.5.3, because it will not do you any good - you will just waste lots of time - the most valuable of all goods known to humanity. Instead, take it as a great opportunity to learn something...

Your belief in the Kalman Filter is a Gaussian distribution, which is unimodal (i.e. it has only one peak at the mean value).

Your belief in the Histogram Filter is a discretized distribution (a histogram!), which can be multimodal (i.e. it can have many peaks, depending only on the values at each bin).

Your belief in a Particle Filter is indirectly represented by the particles, which are samples from the belief distribution. The particles can be placed anywhere in the continuous state space, and can be cluttered at will, so the inherent distribution can be multimodal.
It looks like after the last round of site updates, you'll get this error instead of "your program did not complete". Check to be sure you don't have an endless loop somewhere.
We are talking probabilities, actually... the question wants the expected number of particles, not the actual results from any particular iteration.

    script: main.app

The handlers in your code eg

app = webapp2.WSGIApplication([('/blog', MainHandler),
('/blog/newpost', NewPostHandler),

debug=True)

then map different handlers to different URLs

You only need to change app.yaml if you want to have different python scripts handling different URL's.

@HaydenHm, the distinction that Rosa mentions is important. Action/reaction pairs refer to forces. So if you push on something, it MUST push back.

Note to other students: This goes way beyond what we cover in class. Don't worry if you aren't following (but feel free to ask more questions on the subject!).

As far as we can tell, the gravitational constant (big G, not little g), IS constant throughout the universe.

When energy gets lost to friction it is converted to heat. I suppose you could say that it contributes to global warming, but insignificantly.

Mechanical energy is a term that encompasses both potential and kinetic energy. There are no "other energies," but only because potential energy is a very broad term. There are MANY forms of potential energy and energy can convert between different types of potential and kinetic.

I think the problem is that tension is often presented as a special sort of force. Really, tension is just the name we give to something that can exert a pulling force but not a pushing force (like a rope).

A boat stays afloat due to what people call "the buoyant force." When an object is submerged in a fluid (like water), it feels an upwards force equal to the weight of fluid it has displaced (pushed out of the way). When that upward force is equal to the weight of the boat, it can stay afloat.

This will happen whenever your boat is less dense then water. Note that this doesn't mean the metal that the hull is made of must be less dense than water. It means that the total mass of the boat divided by the total volume (empty space included) must be less than the density of water.

Perhaps this is an area in which Udacity is not going to be competitive with brick-and-mortar institutions. In this environment, students cannot elect to simply take a different section of the same course in order to receive a different version of the instruction. Nevertheless, I think this course was put together in a manner accessible to a vast number of students, which--given the still-experimental nature of this form of education--is quite an accomplishment.

Thanks Brian, that's the kind of answer I was looking for. I did a lot of physics back at college and university and so I should (or at least I hope I would) be able to go through an introductory course quite quickly. I'm thinking of this class as a review, more than a "learning something new" class. But you never know, if something new comes along, it's welcome ;-)

For the sake of debate, I don't think mini-units like unit 8 would be more accessible than a separate course -- maybe pseudo-course, as you brought up, (outside of Udacity's course system) since "there don't need to be a lot of inherent dependencies between some of the new topics".

Firstly, the mini-units don't have titles. "Unit 8 Optional", "Unit 9 Optional", "Unit 10 Optional", ... don't make it easy for pick-and-choose-ing.

Secondly, as we were discussing, the mini-unit looks misplaced -- it's not part of the original syllabus, it's optional, etc.

Having these topics in a separate course, imo, would actually greatly boost accessibility, boost organization, motivate more students, and much more. The main motivation behind us looking for a new course is not so much to see how the topics connect content-wise, as to have a centralized and organized collection of these topics.

As I said, it's probably not enough to easily be able to make a project-driven, very interconnected, traditional Udacity course, but something in between a mini-unit and a Udacity course -- separate from the existing Udacity course system -- would be greatly beneficial. Like a CS101 part II or sequel... CS101.5?

title: Homework#9
body:
Does it matter if the result of homework 9 is a number as a string,
or does it have to be a real number?

The way we have implemented our search engine, we can't have an index (which is a dictionary) where a keyword has no urls or has an empty list as its value. Minimum value is a list of 1 url.

If no keyword is found, our function should output None.
If there is only url associated with a keyword, then no need to sort. We simply result the list containing that 1 url. So, if keyword 'cat' has ['meow.html'] as the only url, we would output 

['meow.html']

Clair's Quote

However, in the problem description, it says: If the list has zero or
one elements, it is already sorted.

Which means if it has one element, (i.e., one url to its name), we
should return that url.

How though, can it be in the dictionary with a count of zero elements,
i.e., no url?

The statement "If the list has zero or one elements, it is already sorted." is referring to your quicksort procedure not to the ordered_search procedure. It is essentially giving you a hint (or rather a very obvious statement) as to the base case of your quicksort procedure. As you pivot and split into 2 lists and then make recursive calls to quicksort, it will eventually happen that either a [] or list with 1 url will get passed to quicksort.

title: Better options for index data structure(scaling)

The AI class format as presented by Prof. Thrum is much more of the entrepreneurial/mentor format, encouraging students to understand at an intuitive level, and to think THROUGH problems and project that understanding forward, PAST the immediate lecture material.

THINK THROUGH, THINK FORWARD!

You have to specify:
1- the new dimensions of the expanded matrix

2- in a list, the new indexes for each of your original rows. So if your original first row is going to be in position 2 in the expanded matrix, your list starts with [2,...]

3- in a list, the new indexes for each of your original cols.

the elements not spanned by the row/cols you listed will be filled with 0. So if you original matrix had 4 rows and 5 cols. you MUST list 4 rows and 5 cols.

Oh and remember that it returns a new matrix so omega= omega.expand

I debated this for a while when I made this video.

I wanted to have ONE number to quantify the error (the 20%) and since the error isn't symmetric (there is higher % error in one direction than the other), I thought that it may just add more confusion to include the negative sign.

But now I think you're right. The negative really ought to be there. Thanks for pointing this out Zeus.

One thing he could have done is take measurements over an extended period of time. The "correct time" would correspond to the shortest shadow measurement (at solar noon when the sun is highest in the sky).
Clever solutions all around. Very cool.

You are absolutely right TC. You've also highlighted a sort of meta-error that exists in scientific experiments: the error of not properly accounting for all your errors!

Humans are imperfect researchers and sometimes there is an unexpected source of error lurking in our experiment. For example, there was recently a claim made that neutrinos travel faster than the speed of light. It turns out there was just an error in the experiment. You can read about it here.

Good point. I used the word constant in two ways. The way galileo first encountered it was in realizing that velocity changes by equal amounts in equal time.

The other point (that acceleration due to g is the same around the world), is fascinating, but not Galileo's realization. Thanks Rosa.

I just wanted something very short that could pass all the tests. Once one gives up on a custom heap structure, simplicity seems like a virtue. I don't think my code is clever, more obvious than anything else - my personal interests are closer to differential topology, dynamical systems and stochastic processes than to CS. If there's an 'idea' at all, it's that letting a heap grow by adding smaller stuff at the top doesn't create that much extra work because, since you always add smaller stuff, it's only the top of the heap pyramid that matters. It's probably possible to write down conditions under which you can just delete the entire bottom of the pyramid; I don't know. I'm a bit too busy at the moment, sadly.
I wondered why you wrote additional methods. Perhaps it's to get the 10x speed advantage? In any case, I welcome your suggestion on speed improvement, and am grateful for your enthusiasm about the course material and for sharing your work!

title: Homework 4.7 Test Cases
body:
If anyone has any interesting test cases please post them here. I made a start. Please don't post solution code, but if you can improve the testing related code that would be fine. And any notes to prevent problems with submitted homework would probably be appreciated. This is a wiki so anyone can edit it. If you edit and make corrections please leave a note about what you did and the reasoning. Thanks!

Edit: it is probably clear to most, but for clarity, this doctest string should be inserted into the lookup function.

First the simplified set:

""" doctest strings

Notes:
This is not approved or endorsed by Udacity. Question everything that you see here
as it may be wrong.

This set should work the same regardless of improvements made to lookup(). I also
removed some checks of special cases - e.g. calling record_user_click() with
non-existant keywords or urls. See the other set if you want to test these cases.

I am now assigning return values to variables since there is always confusion about
returning versus printing on the Udacity forums

*** Udacity Example ***
>>> index = crawl_web('http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index, 'good')

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 0]]

>>> record_user_click(index, 'good', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index, 'good')

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 1]]

*** Extending the example - searching for <body> is a bit odd, but I wanted an interesting new keyword ***
>>> lu =  lookup(index,"<body>")

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/flying.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 0]]

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/flying.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, '<body>', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index,"<body>")

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/flying.html', 1], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html', 2], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 3]]
"""

################################################################################
# Your submission goes here
################################################################################
# Do not turn this part into Udacity - just use it when running a final check
# on their server
#
if __name__ == "__main__":
# OS X Lion
import doctest
doctest.testmod(report=True,verbose=True,exclude_empty=True)
elif __name__ == "main":
# Udacity
import doctest, main
doctest.testmod(main,report=True,verbose=True,exclude_empty=True)

And now the original more controversial set for those who applied the improvements made in HW4.6 to this case. And with a few more boundary cases thrown in just because.

""" doctest strings
Notes:
This is not approved or endorsed by Udacity. Question everything that you see here
as it may be wrong.

This assumes that lookup() won't return the same url multiple times because
the improvements made in Homework 4.6 were applied. **THIS IS DEBATABLE** -
see discussion below, and references to other threads where this has been
discussed.

I am now assigning return values to variables since there is always confusion about
returning versus printing on the Udacity forums

*** Udacity Example ***
>>> index = crawl_web('http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index, 'good')

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 0]]

>>> record_user_click(index, 'good', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index, 'good')

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 1]]

*** Extending the example ***
>>> lu =  lookup(index,"I")

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 0]]

>>> record_user_click(index, 'I', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, 'I', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, 'I', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, 'I', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html')

>>> record_user_click(index, 'I', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html')

>>> lu =  lookup(index,"I")

>>> print lu
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/walking.html', 2], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 3]]

*** Try to break functions now ***

Non-existant keyword, but good url
>>> record_user_click(index, 'this_is_not_a_keyword', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html')

Good keyword, but non-existant url
>>> record_user_click(index, 'good', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/this_is_not_a_url.html')

>>> print lookup(index, 'good')
[['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/index.html', 0], ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/crawling.html', 1]]
"""
#
# Do not turn the above into Udacity - just use it when running a final check
# on their server. Probably safe to submit, but you never know.
################################################################################

# Your submission goes here

################################################################################
# Do not turn this part into Udacity - just use it when running a final check
# on their server
#
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # OS X Lion
    import doctest
    doctest.testmod(report=True,verbose=True,exclude_empty=True)
elif __name__ == "main":
    # Udacity

    doctest.testmod(main,report=True,verbose=True,exclude_empty=True)

There is a problem in the interpreter (also in CS101). It has been reported and they are surely working on it.

It seems to me that breadth-first should visit each node and edge at most one within a small constant (something less then 3 in this problem). As such, it should be an O(nodes + edges) algorithm, which is a good as you can expect for network minimization. Breadth-first benefits from a FIFO queue. I was paranoid about importing deque so I used a list and pop(0), which is O(n) as opposed to O(1) so the algorithm ends up suboptimal.

Sorry about the switch to 9.8 here. This is a symptom of poor planning.

In this unit, the difference between 9.8 and 10 actually seemed relevant, so I made the switch. I had been using 10 previously. If I were to teach this class again, I would use 9.8 throughout.

Breadth-first search is optimal (that is: it finds the optimal path to the goal) because it searches in every direction in a wave that emanates from the start until it finds the goal. A* is an extension of breadth-first search that uses heuristics to focus the search. Because A* doesn't search in every direction equally but only in directions that are likely to lead to the goal, it is much faster than breadth-first and is still optimal if the heuristic is admissible.

This is a great question, and one that deserves some real thought.

$%F = ma$% is the basic law: it says that when an object experiences an unbalanced force, it accelerates. This equation does not identify what provides the force. In fact, the force could be caused by any number of things, it could be gravity, a spring, an electric field, etc... Each of these different specific forces has an equation associated with it. The equation associated with the force of gravity (when we're near the surface of the earth) is...

$%F = mg$%

This equation says, "if you have mass, and you are on the surface of the earth, this is what the force happens to be." If this is the only force on an object, then mg is the unbalanced force we were talking about in $%F = ma$%. In that case, we replace the $%F$% with $%mg$% and we get...

$%mg = ma$%

or...

$%g = a$%

I hope this cleared things up. I will try to film something about this because I think it is a crucial point.

title: Maxmise hw page

Let me know if I'm misinterpreting your question, but I'll take a shot at answering.

In the equation $%F=ma$%, the "m" is somehow a measure of how difficult it is too get an object moving. The greater the m, the more difficult it is to accelerate an object. This idea of difficulty-to-move we call inertia. So the m in $%F=ma$% refers to the object's inertial mass

There is another property that objects have. We can call that property "How much an object reacts to gravity." THAT is the m in $%mg$%, and we can call that the gravitational mass of an object.

So we have these two ENTIRELY DIFFERENT properties of objects. 1- how hard it is to get an object moving and 2- how much an object responds to gravity.

The truly mindblowing thing is that these two properties are both captured in one number, the mass of an object. Wow.

You are doing positive work. Gravity is doing NEGATIVE work, since the force of gravity is in the opposite direction as the direction of motion. You and gravity together do the total work.

Your question can be answered without knowing anything about the population. The biased estimate $%s_n^2$% and unbiased estimate $%s^2$% are properties of the sample, not of the population. (What they both estimate is $%\sigma^2$%, which is a property of the population. $%s_n^2$% is a good estimate for large n, but not for n<30 and certainly not for n=3.)

Start with the sample mean, $%(7 + 13 + 13)/3 = 11$%.

$%s_n^2 = \frac{(7-11)^2 + (13-11)^2 + (13-11)^2}{3} = 8$%

$%s^2 = \frac{(7-11)^2 + (13-11)^2 + (13-11)^2}{2} = 12$%

Note that neither of these is a good estimate if the population contains a value such as $%10^9$%. A sample of three might very well miss important characteristics of the population distribution.

"Population" is indeed a bit ambiguous. You can think of it as that which provides the numbers in our independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.) draws or trials. It could be an urn full of numbered balls, a set of possible die rolls, apple trees in an orchard, NBA players, or whatever. We abstract the population to a "population distribution," which is a mathematical model of the numbers we are drawing. After we finish our analysis, we map the results back into real-world terms.

Of course, we don't have to start with a real-world population. For educational purposes, or as theoreticians, we are free to start with a postulated distribution. That's how we might get
probabilities as our starting point.

@Ivan, you do not need to calculate an approximation in 5-18 but the exact expected value. See this thread for more info:
http://forums.udacity.com/cs215/questions/3710/spoiler-bug-in-randomized-clustering-coefficient/3720

You can try it in the interpreter, doing something like this:

p = [1,2,3] # p is assigned to the list [1,2,3]

proc2(p) # procedure 2 is called, passing the list p to it

print p # the result of this print statement is the list [1,2,3]

In the first line, p is assigned the value of the list [1,2,3]. This means a list is created with the elements [1,2,3] and p refers to that list. If that list is changed (mutated), p will refer to the same list, but the list will have different elements. If p is assigned to a different list, e.g., p = [4,5,6], the original list is unchanged, but p no longer refers to it.

When proc2(p) is called, the list that p refers to is passed to the function. The function creates a local variable (in this case, also called p) that refers to the list passed in. When proc2 makes the assignment p = p + [1], a new list is created and the local variable p refers to the new list. The old list is unchanged because concatenation does not mutate the original list, it creates a new list. And the variable that proc was called on still refers to the old list.

In proc1, the list that p refers to is passed into the function and then mutated. So now, the variable refers to a list that was changed by the function.

Peter, Ben, and DJOldskool are right on. There is a number, called the coefficient of restitution, which quantifies how "bouncy" an object is. When the COR is near one, the ball will return almost to its starting height. As the COR gets smaller, the rebound height gets smaller and smaller.

This coefficient depends, as you would expect, on both the object and the surface: a ball dropped on sand will not bounce as high as a ball dropped on a hard surface.

def set_range(a,b,c):
    if a > b:
        if a > c:
            toprange = a
            if b > c:
                bottomrange = c
            else:
                bottomrange = b
        else:
            if a > b:                
                toprange = c
                bottomrange = b
            return toprange - bottomrange
    else:
        if b > c:
            toprange = b
            if a < c:
                bottomrange = a
            else:
                bottomrange = c
        else:
            toprange = c
            bottomrange = a
return toprange - bottomrange

Almost @ked4r, the thing you are missing is that M isn't really the appropriate thing to use. Better to look at a chunk of the universe with some volume, V. In that case, M is equal to density times Volume. Since V is proportional to r^3, the PE term is actually proportional to r^2. If this is too little explanation (as I suspect it is), check out this article. I hope this helps!
When something is raised to the power of -1, it is the same as putting it in the denominator. So m/s could also be written as m * s^-1

Actually, when you go underwater there are two competing gravitational effects. On one hand, you're right, the smaller r does increase the strength. BUT gravity comes from mass and as you descend there is actually less mass below you. This tends to decrease the strength. It turns out that the decrease wins out over the increase. In fact, there's a cool problem set question on this in unit 5!
The right triangle you are seeing, if I'm seeing what you're seeing, is actually a great way to derive some really cool parts of special relativity like time dilation and length contraction.

This instantly reminded me of the get_next_target() function we did earlier. So, I went in for my first try with that approach in mind:

def split_string(source,splitlist):
result = []
start = 0
for char in source:
    if char in splitlist:
        end = source.find(char, start)
        if source[start:end] != '':
            result.append(source[start:end])
        start = end+1
if source[end:] not in splitlist:
    result.append(source[end+1:])
return result

The tricky part here (one that required a few extra lines to get right) was when the end of the string had no delimiters. Fun exercise... Any suggestions for improvement to this?

title: finding with number quiz unit 1
body: Well, It may seem a little dull but what is the correct answer for the finding the number quiz for unit 1. I have been working on it it, and m quite confused which one is the correct one.

Yes, you stay in the same place. Let's look at this from two points of view. From the point of view of someone on the side of the road, when you jump up, you aren't jumping straight up. You also have some horizontal velocity due to the motion of the truck. In fact, you have the same horizontal velocity as your truck! So if the truck is moving at 10 mph, then when you jump up, you are also jumping forward (from their point of view) at 10 mph. When you land, you and the truck have each moved forward by the same amount, and therefore you land in the same spot on the bed of the truck.

From your point of view: well motion at constant velocity is the same as being at rest. So when you jump straight up, of course you land in the same place, just like you would if you jumped on the ground.

title: One-liner for Question 6.10

def is_palindrome(s):
    return s == '' or (s[0] == s[-1] and is_palindrome(s[1:-1]))

s is palindrome if is empty or their slices are the same and the filling is a palindrome itself.

Javier

def move(self, motion): # Do not change the name of this function

    # ADD CODE HERE
    x, y, theta = self.x, self.y, self.orientation
    alfa, d = motion[0], motion[1]

    L = self.length

    beta = (d / L) * tan(alfa)
    if (beta < 0.001): #straight motion
        theta = self.orientation
        x = x + d*cos(theta)
        y = y + d*sin(theta)
        theta = (theta + beta) % (2*pi)
    else:
        R = d / beta
        theta = self.orientation
        cx = x - sin(theta)*R
        cy = y + cos(theta)*R
        x = cx + sin(theta+beta)*R
        y = cy - cos(theta+beta)*R
        theta = (theta + beta) % (2*pi)

    result = robot(L)
    result.set(x, y, theta)
    return result # make sure your move function returns an instance
                  # of the robot class with the correct coordinates.
As long as you make sure that your function RETURNS the value and policy, you should be good to go!

title: Quiz 5.23 - Empty hash table the easy, Pythonic way!
tagnames: cs101 listcomprehensions pythonic easysolution resources quiz5.23
body:

def make_hashtable(nbuckets):
    return [[] for _ in range(nbuckets)]

This uses "list-comprehensions", a very nice Pythonic construct.

Another possible solution:

def crawl_web(seed,max_pages):
    tocrawl = [seed]
    crawled = []
    while tocrawl:
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            union(tocrawl, get_all_links(get_page(page)))
            crawled.append(page)
            if len(crawled)>= max_pages:
                return crawled
    return crawled

This will not pop any unneeded links since it is checked right after adding crawled which seems natural to me. This solution also does not require the "and" operator. Using break to leave the while loop instead of return crawled might also be an idea since it leaves the procedure with only one return statement, which is a goodthing to me. In the long run tocrawl might also be returned to seed other crawls.

kind regards
Bernd

title: Why don't use dictionaries instead nested lists on unit 4?
body:
In my opinion, it would be easier if Dave had taught dictionaries instead nested lists on Unit 4.

For example:

Peter Norvig was in charge of robotics research at NASA Ames, in what is now the Intelligent Systems Division, until just before I was hired (via a contractor). I developed a website and did news reporting for the Intelligent Systems Program within that division. NASA Ames and JPL were developing competing/cooperating designs for Curiosity's operating system and various subsystems during that time, with JPL being the final integrator.

I learned about the parachute design in a film that NASA made. As I recall, the first problem was to develop a chute strong enough to survive supersonic deployment. Then there was the squiding, which was solved by having a hole at the center of the chute (later converted to a ring gap, a solution that has been used before).

There is much more about the parachute design at http://amyshirateitel.com/2011/06/14/preparing-planetary-parachute/. Where that article differs from anything I've said, accept Amy Shir Teitel's version. She notes, for instance, that we do have previous experience with parachutes on Mars, as well as supersonic tests in Earth's upper atmosphere. We just didn't have experience with a parachute this large, to slow such a massive payload from an initial speed of 1,000 miles per hour (Martian Mach 2.0).
This course will get more difficult in the coming units, but I will try my best to keep it from becoming too unmanageable.

That was incredibly helpful, thank you very much :-)

I still wondering some things, however. I know I'm asking a lot of questions, but I want to have it clear.

So, the whole picture would roughly look like this (please correct me wherever I'm wrong):

1. User tells browser to open http://www.somepage.com/

2. Browser uses DNS to find out www.somepage.com's IP

3. Browser makes http request and sends it to the IP (does this have something to do with "sockets", maybe?)

4. On the server there's a program (a http web server, like Apache, IIS, GWS. Does GAE, or some GAE module, fit here?), which is listening to a specific port (a standardized one, perhaps? If not, how does the browser know which port to send the request?), and analyses the http request, calling the application. In the case of GAE, reads the .yaml file, looks for the path asked by the request (/, /images, /scripts...) and returns the indicated resource (a script, a static_dir...).

5.- When a script is called by the server, it receives the request as an argument, and makes up a response according to it. Here, the script calls other scripts and modules, which may or may not use other modules and libraries (like web or HTML frameworks) and modify a database. The web server takes whatever the application returned and sends it back to the referer indicated in the request.

6.- The referer's browser, which is listening on port 80, receives the response. Finds out what it is (looking up for the MIME of the response, maybe?) and renders it appropriately (unless it is Internet Explorer :-P). Would it need more resources, like images of stylesheets, it would make other requests.
